headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jason Liberty, Chief Financial Officer. Please
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jason Liberty, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paula. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for our fourth quarter earnings call. Joining me here in Miami are Richard Fain, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Adam Goldstein, President and Chief Operating Officer; Michael Ba
componenttext:
Thank you, Paula. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for our fourth quarter earnings call. Joining me here in Miami are Richard Fain, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Adam Goldstein, President and Chief Operating Officer; Michael Bayley, President and CEO of Royal Caribbean International; and Harold Cabezas, our Vice President of Investor Relations.
During this call, we will be referring to a few slides, which have been posted on our investor website, www.rclinvestor.com.
Before we get started, I would like to refer you to our notice about forward-looking statements, which is on our first slide. During this call, we will be making comments that are forward looking. These statements do guarantee future  performance and do involve risks and uncertainties. Examples are described in our SEC filing and other disclosures.
Also we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, which are adjusted as defined, and a reconciliation of these items can be found on our website.
Unless I state otherwise, all metrics are on a constant-currency adjusted basis.
Richard will begin by providing a strategic overview of the business. I will follow with a recap of our fourth quarter and full year results, I will then provide an update on the current booking environment and will end with full year and first quarter guidance for 2016.
We will then open up the call for your questions.
Richard?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jason, and good morning, everyone.As you may heard from Jason's voice, he has a cold this morning. So I'll use this opportunity to wish him a speedy recovery and ask him to sit on the other side of the room.In any event, I'm pleased to have
componenttext:
Thank you, Jason, and good morning, everyone.
As you may heard from Jason's voice, he has a cold this morning. So I'll use this opportunity to wish him a speedy recovery and ask him to sit on the other side of the room.
In any event, I'm pleased to have this opportunity to share more about our results in 2015 and our outlook as we entered 2016.
I admit that it is very satisfying to look back on 2015 and I'd like to take just a moment to celebrate a successful year.
On the revenue side, we achieved our target of 3.5% yield improvement, despite microeconomic and geopolitical challenges that threatened to take us off course. 
I said it before and it still holds true that while many factors may cause disturbances for short periods, our team has shown a very strong capability to make adjustments when circumstances change.
On the cost side, our team worked very hard to control this and we ended the year down 0.6%. We began the year expecting cost to be up 1% or less, where our finance organization and our operations team worked collaboratively to find further efficiencies and our working dollars. 
Looking at the full picture, we anticipated doubling our 2013 earnings per share and we exceeded that target by $0.03 a share at $4.83. The brands in delivering and I congratulate all the employees of our company who worked so hard to make this happen.
It's equally gratifying to note that along with the financial success that we're enjoying, our surveys indicate that the highest levels of employee engagement in our company's history.
Our annual survey had participation levels and indicated higher satisfaction across all categories. We firmly believe that happy employees lead to happy guests and that in turn leads to better yields.
This past year, we took a significant forward -- a significant step forward on this front by establishing hospitality training schools like the one in Tianjin China. This school teaches the art and the science of hospitality, that's an exciting challenge when most of the students have never themselves stayed in a hotel.
The development of this school marks another important step in further deepening our roots with the local community in Mainland, China, as it is a strategy partnership with the Tianjin Maritime College.
In July, we opened the second training school in Indonesia, and in May of 2016, we will open further school in Philippines.
Not only will these schools provide a stream of over 5,000 high-quality employees each year, they provide these individuals the opportunity to join in brand traveling all over the world and improving their community.
We also took a big step forward in our efforts to ensure the long-term health of the oceans by entering into a five-year global partnership with World Wide Life Fund. Our business depends on the health of the oceans, and we feel responsibility to uphold the highest standards of environmental stewardship.
Our partnership with WWF takes our efforts even further by setting specific and measurable targets for carbon emissions, sustainable seafood and destinations to stewardship.
We're serious about looking at our environment and our communities and I'm very pleased to join with the partner, equally passionate about these causes.
Turning to another topic, which we feel passionate about, Double-Double  remains through which we view all our decision-making at Royal Caribbean. Every employee can describe the program. Double 2014 earnings per share and double-digit ROIC by 2017.
As we look at our trajectory, 2015 paved the wave nicely, and the results we were anticipating during 2016 will keep us solidly on our path Double-Double.
The 2 key components of Double-Double to achieving our goals are growing revenue yields and maintaining cost discipline.
From a yield standpoint, our new buildings are attracting and maintaining strong pricing premiums.
Quantum of the Seas in Shanghai above the market and the innovative amenities that distinguish Quantum  are the exact same ones that will make Ovation of the Seas in Tianjin unique in that new market for her.
Finally, after 5 years, we welcoming the third vessel in our Oasis-class, Harmony of the Seas. We've seen the power of the Oasis-class and the longevity of its popularity. Early indications are the Harmony will not disappoint either.
In addition to our new builds outstanding performance, our existing fleet provides returns consistent with our needs of Double-Double.
At the same time, we're continually learning ways to enhance onboard revenue and apply these learnings to the existing fleet to continue to grow revenue yields there as well.
From a cost standpoint, our commitment to cost control remains steadfast. It's an extraordinary coincidence that in both of the past 2 years, net cruise costs, excluding fuel, ended up down 0.6%.
This cost control is not come easy, but we intend to continue to be disciplined in line with our Double-Double targets, but also keeping firmly in mind the strategic needs of the company for the ensuing period.
While I'm pleased to look back on the success of 2015, I'm eager to move on to 2016 and the great things to come.
Our metric indicate that we're still on course for our Double-Double targets, we remain in the solid book position, roughly equal to last year's record levels and at higher rates.
We're currently in the middle of our WAVE Period as I think you all know, and we're happy to report that it is proving to be a solid wave, as we have seen geopolitical concerns can also threaten the demand environment from time-to-time.
These to pockets of our portfolio and we generally manage through them.
It's important to note that when demand in one area of the globe is weaker, many times there's an increase in demand for other destinations. Our intent is to maximize the overall portfolio and we see that as one of the benefits of being a global player.
Although, the current strength of the overall market is a key driver, we attribute part of our favorable book position to our price integrity policy. As a reminder, our price integrity policy is our determination to avoid the common prior practice of implementing dramatic last-minute discounts, which cheapen our brand and upset our loyal customers.
The policy says that we will not implement any new discounts during the last weeks before selling with the time period varying by the length of the cruise. We first started this policy about a year ago, and we've made a number of tweaks to it as we perfected our formula.
In December, we decided to make the policy even clearer and broader. It continues to apply in the U.S., Canada, the U.K. and Ireland. Altogether, by the way those represent more than 2/3 of our revenue.
But we did decide that having different rules for different itinerary links was possibly confusing and definitely unnecessary.
We have therefore expanded the policy to make the know new discount period consistently 30 days regardless of itinerary.
The only exception continues to be 3- or 4-night sailings which are traditionally late bookers.
All of this makes the policy easier to understand and to implement.
We are strong believer that clarity and specificity in the program like this is important, because otherwise, the exceptions undermine the integrity of the program even if they are, in fact, very rare.
We now think we've got it right and we do not expect more changes in the near future.
At this time, we've had our policy in place for almost a year, and we have a better view of the results.
During this time, we have granted no exceptions to the policies since its adoption, and we have no intention of doing so now. Nevertheless, we've seen a double-digit percentage improvement in the booking window over this period and we believe that the policy help solidify brand preference.
An unforeseen benefit, we have found is the reduced number of bookings taken in a discount before we get to the focus period.
Living the spirit of the policy is helped our revenue managers make better pricing decisions, and it has been roundly applauded by the travel agents that are so central to our success.
When we introduced the policy, we'd transparent with you all that the upfront cost would result from some cabins going empty rather than being filled at deep last minute discounts. We know that in 2016, we will still see some residual impact leading to these empty cabins, but by 2017, we feel comfortable that the impact will be positive.
One last point I would like to touch on before turning it back to Jason is our share repurchase program. As you will recall, we announced a repurchase program during our call last October. That full program totals $500 million. Of the total, $200 million was part of an accelerated repurchase program, which we have completed. We expect to continue to purchase opportunistically throughout the year 2016 until before $500 million is completed. 
With that, it's a pleasure turn it back to Jason.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard. I will begin by taking you through our results for the fourth quarter.We have summarized our fourth quarter results on Slide 2. For the quarter, we generated adjusted net income of $0.94 per share, which was $0.04 above our guidance.
componenttext:
Thank you, Richard. I will begin by taking you through our results for the fourth quarter.
We have summarized our fourth quarter results on Slide 2. For the quarter, we generated adjusted net income of $0.94 per share, which was $0.04 above our guidance. 
Net revenue yields were up 4.9%, which was at the high-end of our expectations. A combination of new hardware, a stronger Caribbean and a successful new winter season in China helped drive the robust year-over-year improvement. Costs were 70 basis points better than guidance for the quarter, with net cruise costs, excluding fuel, down 4.7%.
I will now discuss full year results, which we've summarized on Slide 3. This year, we had record earnings and exceeded the $1 billion market. Adjusted net income was $1.07 billion, resulting in adjusted earnings per share of $4.83. These record earnings also mark a second consecutive year of 40-plus percent growth in earnings.
Revenue yields increased 3.5% for the full year.
Yield improvements in the Caribbean, Europe and China more than offset weakness in Latin America.
Onboard revenue yield did not disappoint with a year-over-year improvement of 4%. The combination of new hardware, more onboard revenue venues on our upgraded ships and VOOM, the drove the majority of this improvement. We delivered a second consecutive year of costs improvement on a per unit with net cruise costs, excluding fuel, down 0.6%.
These costs improvements occurred in nonguests areas, mainly through identifying further synergies amongst our brands and leveraging scale in our back office.
Now I'd like to update you on what we're seeing in the demand environment. I will start by taking you through first quarter trends. 63% of Q1 capacity is in the Caribbean, 23% is in the Asia Pacific region and approximately 11% is in Brazil and Latin America.
The quarter as a whole has booked ahead of last year in both load factor and rate. Overall, we're seeing strong yield trends in Q1, driven by a significant year-over-year improvement in Caribbean and the addition of the winter China season. The strength of these 2 products is more than offsetting ongoing price and pressures in Latin America and Australia.
The WAVE Period is off to a good start with bookings for Q2 to Q4 sailings trending similarly to last year's level. As we entered Wave, we had significantly fewer staterooms left to sell on first quarter sailings in last year. 
So as expected, bookings for the first quarter have been lower than last year. For the full year, we're booked at a similar load factor to last year's record high and at a higher
 
Capacity is increasing 6.3% year-over-year as we welcome Harmony of the Seas and Ovation of the Seas into the fleet this spring.
The majority of our capacity growth is in the Asia Pacific region with the balance mostly in the Caribbean.
capacity will be up about 4% year-over-year as the product benefits from an upgrade hardware. In addition to Anthem of the Seas in the North East, we'll have a least 2 Oasis-class ships in the Caribbean in each quarter. We're also moderately increasing capacity in Europe driven by a handful of sailings on Ovation of the Seas before she began her journey to China. 
Once she arrives in China, Ovation will contribute to our 33% capacity growth in the Asia Pacific region. On the other hand, we've significantly scaled back our capacity in Brazil and Latin America. While these products will account for approximately 11% our capacity  in the first quarter, they will be reduced to less than 2% for the remainder of the year.
We're seeing particular strength from the North American consumer and our Caribbean and Alaska products are currently booked at record low factors. The Caribbean  accounts for 43% of our 2016 capacity and has booked ahead of same time last year in both load factor and rate.
Our Caribbean product consists of a wide variety of itineraries, ranging from weekend getaways to 14-night selling Caribbean  sailings. In general, we're seeing better trends than last year across Caribbean itineraries with 7-night and shorter sailings showing the most strength.
Overall, we're expecting mid-single digit yield growth for the Caribbean.
Alaska has booked nicely ahead of last year in both rate and volume, despite a 6% year-over-year increase in capacity. We anticipate mid-single-digit yield growth and what is expected to be a record-breaking year for the product.
Europe itineraries account for about 21% of our 2016 capacity. Although booked load factors for the product is slightly lower than same time last year's record levels, recent trends have been quite strong and load factor remains nicely higher than at this point in all other previous years.
We did experience a softening in North American demand for a short period after the Paris attacks in November. And there was a minor drop in bookings from European sourced markets. Demand quickly returned to typical levels, although pricing remains a low same time last year for Eastern Mediterranean sailings.
Prices for like hardware for Europe are up slightly versus same time last year. Overall, we're expecting a low single-digit yield decline for our European itineraries, primarily driven by hardware changes and pricing pressure and itinerary modifications that relate to be Eastern Mediterranean.
Asia Pacific itineraries will account for 19% of our 2016 capacity, following significant growth in both Australia and China. Yields for the Asia Pacific product as a whole are expected to be up low single digits, driven mainly by our increasing capacity and the high-yield in China market.
For the first time, we'll offer a year round china product as Quantum of the Seas make Shanghai her home for the full year. Her sister ship Ovation of the Seas will drive the remainder of our China capacity growth after she arrives in Tianjin at the end of June.
Significant industry capacity growth combined with the expansion of the season into off-peak periods and embarkation points -- ports has led us to forecast a low single-digit yield decline for China in 2016.
Nevertheless, China is expected to remain one of our highest yielding itineraries and is contributing to the company's overall yield growth.
The pricing environment in Australia remains a bit of a challenge given ongoing capacity growth in the region and the weakening of the Australian dollar. While Australia continues to deliver a strong seasonal yield, we expect yield in Australia to be flat to slightly down for the year.
Before getting into our 2016 guidance, I wanted to reiterate some of our previous comments we made during our last earnings call that relate to Pullmantur.
As a result of these -- of our rightsizing efforts, we expect to incur restructuring and related costs in the range of $0.05 to $0.10 per share during 2016. 
Additionally, as previously discussed, we intend on eliminating Pullmantur's two-month accounting lag during the first quarter of 2016. This change will result in a 14-month reporting period for Pullmantur this year with an estimated earnings per share by $0.10. 
For simplification and comparative purposes, we will be excluding all of these one-time adjustments from our key statistics. Hence, our GAAP earnings in 2016 will be slightly lower for these adjustments.
In all this into account, if you turn to Slide 4, you will see our guidance for 2016. This will be the second full year on our path towards Double-Double and our results remain on track. 
Net yields are expected to be up for the seventh consecutive year, with yield increasing 2% to 4%. Strong trends from North American products, additional capacity in the Asia Pacific region and another year of strong onboard revenue are expected to drive this improvement.
On the onboard side, new hardware and upgrades to our existing ships, a greater mix of capacity in Asia and further expansion of VOOM is expected to deliver another step change in shipboard revenue yield.
Net cruise costs, excluding fuel, are expected to be up 1% or less for the full year. While the full year demonstrates our cost discipline, the cadence of expenses through the year is linear. For example, our ddrydock in 2016 are concentrated in the first and fourth quarter. 
In addition, you will recall that in the second quarter of last year, we made investments in the China market to support Quantum of the Seas. This year, these investments are being made slightly earlier to support our year around China presence, Ovation of the Seas of arrival and to grow our Asia market footprint.
This is resulting in a shift and spend into the first quarter.
We anticipate fuel expense of $716 million for the year, and we're 66% hedged. Over the past several months, fuel prices have significantly weakened, while the U.S. dollar has continued to strengthen versus our currencies. 
The combination of these 2 factors has resulted in a $0.14 per share headwind to 2016 earnings. Additionally, the recent rise in interest rates has impacted our 2016 earnings by $0.06 per share.
Based on current fuel prices, currency exchange rates and interest rates, we expect another record-breaking year with earnings per share between $5.90 and $6.10 per share.
The midpoint of this guidance represents a year-over-year increase of 24%, which comes on the heels of more than 40% growth delivered in each of the past 2 years.
Now I would like to walk you through our first quarter guidance on Slide 5. Net yields are expected to be up approximately 4% for the first quarter, driven by a strong Caribbean and the continuation of the winter season for Quantum in China. Net cruise costs, excluding fuel, are expected to be up in the range of 4.5% to 5%, driven by a combination of factors. 
We're setting the groundwork for 2 new ships -- 2 new ship entries later this year, while also maximizing the moment of new marketing campaigns for our 2 largest brands during Wave.
Additionally, we will be investing earlier this year in Asia, as we look to continue to expand our leadership position in the market and diversify our channel mix.
As I mentioned earlier, much of this spend has been concentrated in the first quarter due to timing. Taking all this into account, we expect adjusted earnings per share for the quarter to be approximately $0.30. 
With that, I would ask our operator to open up the call for a question-and-answer session.

componenttextpreview: Tim, So as it relates to bookings over the past 120 days, they basically have had a similar cadence to last year. Now obviously, markets like China that are later in the bookings cycle can influence that. So if you look at what the cadence has been for No
componenttext: Tim, So as it relates to bookings over the past 120 days, they basically have had a similar cadence to last year. Now obviously, markets like China that are later in the bookings cycle can influence that. So if you look at what the cadence has been for North America and Europe, it's been slightly higher versus same time last year. So our book position would be slightly better if you were to account for the mix shift change in China. As it relates to Canada, there's nothing I would say that specific that we've seen that is different from no And again, as it relates to China, it's coming in as we would expected to.

componenttext: Well, on the Canada side, I would just take our commentary as it relates to the Caribbean and we're in a very good book position, we're in a very good price position as it relates to the North American consumer. And China obviously, we're guiding for yields to be slightly down. A lot of that, again, is driven by further expanding into the other seasons and also expanding into secondary markets and ports.

componenttextpreview: And Tim, on the question of the discounting policy, the previous policy had depending on the length of the cruise, different -- we had different periods. So in some cases, we said there be no discounting within last 10 days, in some last 20, some last 30
componenttext: And Tim, on the question of the discounting policy, the previous policy had depending on the length of the cruise, different -- we had different periods. So in some cases, we said there be no discounting within last 10 days, in some last 20, some last 30 and some in the last 40, and people weren't sure. which apply to which and we thought it was easier both from the publics point of view, but also a key driver of this is from our own revenue managers point of view. And so it's important that we have a clear policy that everybody understood and could follow and we decided to expand it to 30 days across the board except for the 3 and 4 nights.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Michael. Yes, I think, China '16 is a different kind of configuration from China '15 because, as Jason had mentioned, we've got deeper push into the secondary ports with one of our ships with a broader seasons and we've got more capacity in Q
componenttext: Tim, this is Michael. Yes, I think, China '16 is a different kind of configuration from China '15 because, as Jason had mentioned, we've got deeper push into the secondary ports with one of our ships with a broader seasons and we've got more capacity in Q1 and Q4. So it's a different kind of conflagration and our inventory is being released in the slightly different way in '16 than '15. I think, as Jason had mentioned, we're feeling that our bookings are coming in as expected.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, let me just add one thing, I know you know this, but for some of the others, when we talk about the broader season, Quantum of the Seas was unusual for the first time we're doing year around in China. Previously, we've only been there seasonally. So
componenttext: Tim, let me just add one thing, I know you know this, but for some of the others, when we talk about the broader season, Quantum of the Seas was unusual for the first time we're doing year around in China. Previously, we've only been there seasonally. So what we decided was there was year around opportunity and while we don't get us much in the winter in China as we get in the summer in China like any other market, we do well in the winter and so when -- but when you average it brings down the average, but as it relates to overall China, actually is helping us in our improvement in 2016.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Felicia Hendrix from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Felicia Hendrix from Barclays.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did have a question on China we're on that topic, let's stick there. So we have strong demands, you have a little bit of a different cadence this year because you're in the first and fourth quarter, which is seasonally priced have a different mix, which
componenttext: I did have a question on China we're on that topic, let's stick there. So we have strong demands, you have a little bit of a different cadence this year because you're in the first and fourth quarter, which is seasonally priced have a different mix, which you just mentioned, but overall, demand is strong and you guys said that yields were up low single digits driven by China, so that's all good. What I was hoping you could clarify that we get a lot of questions just about the charter companies, the charter agents and the status there, I think their view is that some of the charter agents are losing money on the China cruises in general, I just wondering whether or not that's actually true and if there are issues what is Royal Caribbean doing if anything to fix that? And then also I'm just wondering if you're seeing any differences in how different Chinese brands are performing there versus your brand and others, how you differentiated, you did mention that you guys performed better than everyone else in the market?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Felicia. Just to correct one point, the yields are down in China this year '16 versus '15 based upon all of the different elements that we just talked about. With regards to charter companies, it's quite a mix in relation to our total distribution, but ov
componenttext: Felicia. Just to correct one point, the yields are down in China this year '16 versus '15 based upon all of the different elements that we just talked about. With regards to charter companies, it's quite a mix in relation to our total distribution, but over time obviously, we're being changing the mix of our distribution and we continue that journey. So literally every single year, we're doubling the number of agents selling Royal Caribbean in the China market. And of course, we're broadening regional footprint, especially, now with the introduction of Ovation in Tianjin. So it's true that some of the charter companies really out of Shanghai had some challenges in '15 in relation to in Korea and of course, the typhoon season, which was particularly difficult. And so some of the charters did experience some losses during some of the sailings, but having said that, they did particularly well the rest of the year with Royal Caribbean and have done well with Royal Caribbean over the past 9 years that we've been in the market. So there was a bit of a hiccup and of course, we -- as we are in The United States, we're long-term partners with our travel partners. So we've worked hard it finding some workarounds with them in terms our '16 inventory and how we work with them in terms of our cooperative marketing and this type of thing. So we feel that we've been very responsive to some of the feedback that we've had from some of these chartes. And we think we're in a fairly good position for '16. With regards to the differentiation of the brands, that's, I think, a highly relevant question. When you look at Royal Caribbean against the competition, we have been in the market now for 9 years and we've been investing over a 9-year period in the market. We have the newest hardware in the key ports, Quantum of the Seas has been a huge hit Shanghai, Ovation coming into Tianjin is doing very well. We have 8 consecutive years of being the top cruise line in China awarded by the Travel Trade Gazette and the Travel Weekly. We've been focused on launching consumer campaigns and we're -- in fact, we're launching a new campaign literally in the coming weeks. We've been working on expanding our distribution footprint and of course, we're the largest single cruise brand in China with a really professional and competent sales organization and marketing team who really have been with us for quite some time. So I think the spread between Royal Caribbean, international and the competing brands in the market is quite significant and a lot of that is driven by the hardware, Quantum and Ovation world-class leading hardware and they are the only brand-new ships in the China market.

componenttext: Jason, thank you for the cadence of the cost in the quarter, that was want to make questions, but to add on to that, if you look at how your costs trended in 2015 versus your original guidance for the full year, they came in better-than-expected or lower-than-expected, so I was wondering what drove that and do you think you can achieve a similar result in 2016?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that there is as it relates to 2015 is this is really a corporate enterprise-wide effort on trying to identify our cost improvements, and so as I said in the past, it's not one thing, it's thousands of little things that we do. The leadershi
componenttext: Well, I think that there is as it relates to 2015 is this is really a corporate enterprise-wide effort on trying to identify our cost improvements, and so as I said in the past, it's not one thing, it's thousands of little things that we do. The leadership, for example has given around supply chain and that team, the consolidation of our marine organization and finally, more efficiencies in our back-office is really what we just do day-to-day when we use the lines of Double-Double, and so that  is ongoing and continuing. There are a lot of headwinds in costs in 2016. Obviously, as we spend on mix into Asia, the cost of operating there is higher and some more upfront cost in the sales and marketing side as we're delivering 2 new ships this year. And also having VOOM, the fastest Internet bandwidth at Sea also has a high cost to it. So there are a lot of headwinds, but our efforts to try to continue to identify opportunity is never ending, but I think we think the 1% of less guidance is really our best view based all of our plans that we have to date to manage cost-effectively in 2016.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Felicia, I will just add something. I do think that the Jason's focus on this is very helpful, but all of our leaders here Adam, Lisa, Michael, the others are really very focused on it. I'd also just maybe take the opportunity and talk a little bit about
componenttext: Felicia, I will just add something. I do think that the Jason's focus on this is very helpful, but all of our leaders here Adam, Lisa, Michael, the others are really very focused on it. I'd also just maybe take the opportunity and talk a little bit about the timing of it during the year. You know I've said this in previous calls, we manage on an annual basis, and one thing that's unique about our business that I think distinguishes us from many others is that we have some significant big cost that we can shift around in terms of timing. So we would look at a booking pattern to say whether we order drydock ship in March or April, or September or October or what you have, and when we make those decisions, we simply don't pay attention internally to whether that falls at this quarter or that quarter, but those kinds of what we think of those as immaterial tweaking to get the best outcome, particularly, as it relates, for example, if I take a dry docking, we might find that for whatever reason, we were just booking better at the end of September than early October and we would just decide to shift drydock by if 1 quarter into another. From an operating point of view, they're I immaterial and those kinds of changes can actually help us in bringing our overall cost number down. But I fully recognize that as it relates to the individual quarters, they will distort the numbers. And unfortunately, that's simply a fact of life and we think our best strategy is to continue to focus on the year, we want to -- if it's cheaper for us to do in the March than April, we will do it in March rather than in April and the Double-Double, and so Double-Double has really been very helpful. You talked about our cost containment over the last number of years now, the Double-Double is actually a very helpful concept if everybody can focus on it and move towards that common goal. So I think that's why we had the results that we've had, but I do acknowledge it does relate to bumps in any given quarter or period.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will have in our filing that breakdown, but I know for the full year, our 2 largest exposures will be in the pound, and the then Australian dollar, Canadian dollar and then the euro, that will be the cadence for the year. And then obviously, there's so
componenttext: We will have in our filing that breakdown, but I know for the full year, our 2 largest exposures will be in the pound, and the then Australian dollar, Canadian dollar and then the euro, that will be the cadence for the year. And then obviously, there's some changes and based off the sourcing or other deployment during the course of the year. So for example, there is more exposure to the Southern Hemisphere markets like Brazil and Australia. In the wintertime and in the summertime, you're more exposed to Europe. So you have more pound, euro as well as because it's more of a peak period for the Chinese consumer.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to china a quick, I have a two-part question. I guess first, and Jason you said this before, I guess, when you say yields will be down in 2016, can you break that yield factor down for us? Meaning, how much is ticket price versus onboard? Wh
componenttext: So going back to china a quick, I have a two-part question. I guess first, and Jason you said this before, I guess, when you say yields will be down in 2016, can you break that yield factor down for us? Meaning, how much is ticket price versus onboard? What I'm trying to get is, is that onboard spending  holing up? And then second, Jason, you've already talked about the profitability forecast basis in China and how much stronger that is versus other markets, is that profitability on a customer base is still holding up despite the ticket prices coming back in?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, so as it relates our yields being slightly down in 2016, the is more concentrated on the mix of the secondary markets and a seasonality and then there is some pressure, as Michael talked about, on just general ticket. And that obviously, when you h
componenttext: Steve, so as it relates our yields being slightly down in 2016, the is more concentrated on the mix of the secondary markets and a seasonality and then there is some pressure, as Michael talked about, on just general ticket. And that obviously, when you have ship like Ovation come in, that helps balance out some of the pressures we have on some of our older assets that are in the market, really non-Quantum class assets. The mix between ticketing onboard is actually pretty similar. You would index a little bit higher on the onboard side because you have Quantum coming in to the market. Now the point on profitability of the Chinese guests, it is still very much there. China is one of our highest yielding markets, the Quantum is one of our highest yielding products. It does -- it's a little bit more expensive to operate, but it also we get yields for those products. So it is very much contributing to our yields and it is very much contributing to our profits and our margins and our business, and I think our -- which is why our outlook continues to be very favorable for the Chinese market.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And then second question on your buyback, I know you have $300 million left at this point, I mean, the stock is, obviously, under some decent pressure here today, and it's basically if you look at your $7 adjusted EPS number for next year,
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then second question on your buyback, I know you have $300 million left at this point, I mean, the stock is, obviously, under some decent pressure here today, and it's basically if you look at your $7 adjusted EPS number for next year, you're trading at basically sub-10x earnings at this point. So I guess, my question is probably for Richard, I mean, that -- as $300 million is only, call, 2% of your shares outstanding, how receptive will the board be when you go back to them and say, hey, we potentially need more than the $500 million that was originally out there?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we made the decision certainly without seeing or expecting this kind of the reaction here. And as I said, we -- I think the board and the management felt very good about the trajectory we're on, and nothing has changed in our view as to what our act
componenttext: Well, we made the decision certainly without seeing or expecting this kind of the reaction here. And as I said, we -- I think the board and the management felt very good about the trajectory we're on, and nothing has changed in our view as to what our actual -- the word that I keep here uses cadence, but I would say the pattern of our earnings growth over the next couple of years. So our view on the business is very constant. I think I'm always little cautious to speak on behalf of the board something like this because this is a sort of thing that everybody looks at, but we did see that this was -- there was appropriate to do a share buyback. We also will temper our enthusiasm as it relates to the shares because it is our attention to become an investment grade company, and I think we would take that as a consideration factor as well. So I certainly don't think there's been any negative change in the general view, but I don't think the board would tend to be knee-jerk on, particularly, in short-term change in the share price.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Just on that last point, the short-term reactions to the prices do provide the board an opportunity to get more aggressive, can you give us a sense of  if you do hit your earnings target, your EBITDA targets, what's your leverage ratio is going to be at the end of the year, and does that give you -- how much room does that give you to perhaps use your balance sheet a bit more aggressively because this share price 10x earnings, those are typically really, really good opportunities to invest in your stock?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Harry, I'll just comment on kind of where we see ourselves on a ratio perspective and our leverage to comment on more in terms of how we interact on the board side, but I think we see ourselves based off of the guidance that we've been given that we wi
componenttext: So Harry, I'll just comment on kind of where we see ourselves on a ratio perspective and our leverage to comment on more in terms of how we interact on the board side, but I think we see ourselves based off of the guidance that we've been given that we will be at or slightly below our targets by the end of 2016. Now whether that -- the timing of when the rating agencies decide to provide us that rating is not only subject to the metric, but also subject to how we as a corporation are behaving like an investment grade credit. So as Richard said, as we look at, do we -- do more or less, a lot of that comes into keeping the balance of our growth, the balance of returning capital to shareholders and also becoming an investment grade credit, and those will be key things that are always evaluated when we determine how much we will buyback or how much the program will be that we announced.

componenttext: Go ahead, go ahead, Harry

componenttext: going with this is that your -- there is the leverage ratio, there is also the interest coverage ratio, which is probably by the end of this year going to be somewhere between 8.5 and 9x and given the low-cost of your debt, and so I just want to point out that there are opportunities for accounting companies to be really opportunistic and it would seem that if you can do $7 a share next year that this is one of those opportunities.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and as I think as you've made clear in sort of this back-and-forth, there are a lot of things that go into that equation. I'm going to be very cautious not to preempt the board on something that a board rightfully focuses on carefully, but I think th
componenttext: Yes, and as I think as you've made clear in sort of this back-and-forth, there are a lot of things that go into that equation. I'm going to be very cautious not to preempt the board on something that a board rightfully focuses on carefully, but I think those are the things, it's the opportunity when there is what appears to be a downturn in the share price. On the other, there is the need to make sure that we have the appropriate capital for our new building program and this is, of course, a capital-intensive business, and we also do want to get to investment grade. So the board will have to balance those things, but obviously, what's happening in the market would -- will be something that we'll be looking at very closely.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll just get -- I'll get off the bucks and ask an operating question, and going back to China, Jason, if you look at your pricing like-for-like, your pricing in China is being dragged down just by the timing of the introduction of your ships, is it
componenttext: Okay. I'll just get -- I'll get off the bucks and ask an operating question, and going back to China, Jason, if you look at your pricing like-for-like, your pricing in China is being dragged down just by the timing of the introduction of your ships, is it fair or is it relevant to try and look at pricing on a like period -- for like period, particularly, for example, with the Quantum?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, we really trying to have the general conversation about the region versus the market itself. And the reason for that is, is because China has to work with also the winter season, which means Australia and Southeast Asia need to work. So t
componenttext: Well, first off, we really trying to have the general conversation about the region versus the market itself. And the reason for that is, is because China has to work with also the winter season, which means Australia and Southeast Asia need to work. So that's -- it is and it continues to continue to the overall yield of the region. Quantum  continues to perform as we expected and performed well. There has been a little bit of like-for-like pressure on the order tonnage that is -- we have in that marketplace, but the Quantum Class ships continue to demand a premium to the relative pricing that's in the marketplace. I also think it's important to point out -- I know there's been a lot of concern about what's happening in the China marketplace with the consumer, and I think that the patterns that we're seeing with the Chinese consumer continue to show that they have a strong sentiment and a very strong desire for cruise. And a lot of the pressure on pricing just has to do with a lot of capacity coming in more seasonality in terms of the China offering and us going into other markets, which we've talked about before.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think that, certainly, we get into an economic conversation. I think it could, obviously, create more demand for some of their exported products and that could potentially improve their wallet in which they can spend more on the cruise side. Again, the in China is quite good, and I think that their demand, especially, for our products have continued to cadence that we had expected.

componenttext: Couple of questions, please. First with China. Roughly what was the average premium you generated last year versus rest of the group? And the other question looking at year customer deposits of $1.7 billion at the end of the year, they were actually slightly lower than a year ago, and yet your book position is similar, you got higher prices, you got more capacity, I was wondering whether that's a currency impact or is that some China or something else, of course

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, on the China premium we talked publicly about in terms of specific number. Obviously, we're happy with the margins and yields we get in that market as we add more capacity in, so you could follow where the investment is going. And then as it relate
componenttext: Jamie, on the China premium we talked publicly about in terms of specific number. Obviously, we're happy with the margins and yields we get in that market as we add more capacity in, so you could follow where the investment is going. And then as it relates to -- on the deposit side, it's a combination of few things. Some of that is currency related. Some of that also as we expand our mix into China, the cadence of deposits are much closer or their payment is much closer to the time of sailing because it's a late booking market than it is for other markets, so that squeezes it a little. And also there is different promotional activity we do where you might probably less a deposit down and that's really what kind of drives that differential in the customer deposit line on the balance sheet.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just was wondering who you compare yourself to because to only have your net cruise costs, ex fuel, up 0.5% relative to really any other industry or really any other stock we have undercovered seems pretty good and it's actually slightly below CCL's cost
componenttext: Just was wondering who you compare yourself to because to only have your net cruise costs, ex fuel, up 0.5% relative to really any other industry or really any other stock we have undercovered seems pretty good and it's actually slightly below CCL's cost guidance, so on these cost headwinds seem -- I mean, you've spent a lot of time on them, I just want to understand whether there is a reason for that and why there is so much focus on it? And then separately, is your compensation linked to achieving those cost guidance forecast? Then one other thing, for FX, the spread between your 2016 constant net yield and current net yield guidance of 200 basis points was bigger than what we were expecting, can you just give us a little bit more color on that FX breakdown?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, thank you for those comments. Thank you, particularly, for the first comment. Yes, we think the cost performance has been excellent for a number of years now and we're quite proud of the work. And I think the fact that it comes at the same time th
componenttext: Steven, thank you for those comments. Thank you, particularly, for the first comment. Yes, we think the cost performance has been excellent for a number of years now and we're quite proud of the work. And I think the fact that it comes at the same time that our level of guest satisfaction goes up as it's important feature for us because I think it's actually relatively easy to cut cost, if you don't care about the products to deliver to your guests, but we have been raising guest satisfaction while we've been cutting cost, and as you say this level of cost discipline is actually quite good. There are couple of things. One, we'll take credit for which is that we -- I think the management team has done a really very good job of looking for new ways of doing things, new efficiencies, et cetera. The other is and we did telegraph this when we're doing it, which is that we spend money which we thought would result in savings later on. And so -- and we talked about some of those things, we talked about the IT spending, we talked about some of the other stuff that we would doing, and so I think that also helps us a little bit by comparison. So -- but we're not resting on our that, we think there is more to be done continual efficiencies because even the guidance we've given, which now is for 2016, up marginally. Obviously, the inflation in the areas that we're looking at is higher than that. The answer to your second question was the compensation, yes. Our compensation is all the management teams compensation has a number of factors. One of which is, specifically, net cruise costs, excluding fuel, but on the other hand, another one of which is net revenue yields, another one is safety and environment. So we're trying to make sure that we're meeting our cost goals, our revenue goals, but also not doing things that put us in risk. This is a long-term business and we've worked hard to put Royal Caribbean in a position where it is solid on, if you will bottom line as well as just the earnings per share. I'm going to let Jason handle the last of those questions.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve. Obviously, the headwinds of currency have continued, especially, at our hedged position on fuel outpace, the benefits we've been receiving from a fuel. If you just look at year-over-year, our currencies is down 10% year-over-year and that's really
componenttext: Steve. Obviously, the headwinds of currency have continued, especially, at our hedged position on fuel outpace, the benefits we've been receiving from a fuel. If you just look at year-over-year, our currencies is down 10% year-over-year and that's really what's driving that differential between reported and the constant currency and some of the currencies, for example which had very little volatility has become more volatile more recently as it's been unhitched from the U.S. dollar.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions actually. One is on China. You have talked about being likely to maybe add more ships there, you don't have anything announced for 2017 or after that, and I'm just wondering what your kind of most recent thoughts on that are versus where they
componenttext: 2 questions actually. One is on China. You have talked about being likely to maybe add more ships there, you don't have anything announced for 2017 or after that, and I'm just wondering what your kind of most recent thoughts on that are versus where they were sort of 2 or 3 months ago? And then, outside of China, your commentary and the release talks about volume being a kind of -- load being at the same level as last year, but price higher, and in October, both volume and -- both load and price were up. And obviously, your volume can only be up at end of the day as most of your supply is up, so I guess,, I'm wondering if the lower volume now versus October just kind of relative to your book position of the prior year, is that pretty much in line with your expectations that because you're raising price that you're going to expect volume to slow between October and now?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, it's Michael, just to answer your first question on China and more ships. Obviously, we don't make any announcements on new ships until we make the announcements that have been made already for 2017. So when we're ready, we'll announce. But I think
componenttext: Robin, it's Michael, just to answer your first question on China and more ships. Obviously, we don't make any announcements on new ships until we make the announcements that have been made already for 2017. So when we're ready, we'll announce. But I think, overall, we continue to be very positive about the opportunity in China. It's the beginning of something that we think is really, really positive. So our intention is to continue to invest and grow that market.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Robin, on the volume and price side just add on the October call, we said we were booked ahead on both the rate and volume. Outside of the little hiccups we saw as it relates to the Paris attacks and some of the geopolitical events, which quickly boun
componenttext:
And Robin, on the volume and price side just add on the October call, we said we were booked ahead on both the rate and volume. Outside of the little hiccups we saw as it relates to the Paris attacks and some of the geopolitical events, which quickly bounced back, it has been very much in line with our expectations. And as we have a greater mix of our capacity going into China, that does skew the year-over-year comparables because it is much closer in booking environment, but I would describe it overall that it's in line with our expectations.
Thank you for your assistance with the call today and we thank all of you for your participation and the interest in the company. Carol will be available for any follow-ups you might have and I really do wish you all have a great day.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
