headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions here for you. First, on onboard, just give us some more color on -- obviously, you called out beverage and Internet, but is the trend that you experienced here in the first quarter something that we can look to continue in the second, third
componenttext: Two questions here for you. First, on onboard, just give us some more color on -- obviously, you called out beverage and Internet, but is the trend that you experienced here in the first quarter something that we can look to continue in the second, third and fourth quarters? That being first. And then second on Shanghai, you called that out in your China commentary, maybe give a little more color on what -- your experience in China to take that down to the bottom end of the range.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So on the onboard side, I think this general trend is something that we do continue to expect to see. Obviously, an 8.7% growth is wonderful and I don't think we expect that same level of rate going forward because there are some year-over-year com
componenttext: Great. So on the onboard side, I think this general trend is something that we do continue to expect to see. Obviously, an 8.7% growth is wonderful and I don't think we expect that same level of rate going forward because there are some year-over-year comps that become more challenging. But I would say that the brands are adding a lot more to the offering. They're doing more on a pre-cruise sales perspective. On the Internet side, there'll be more and more Royal ships that will have VOOM as we go into Q2 and beyond. And also, in the first quarter, Celebrity introduced Xcelerate, that's with an X, which is not to the same level as VOOM but is far superior to the Internet capabilities relative to the competitive set. So I think overall, the trends, and we've had several years now of positive trends, should continue.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the question on Shanghai, I mean, obviously, we look at China. Typically, everybody looks at it as one market. But really, of course, it's 3 markets, it's the north and it's the south and it's Shanghai, and we have presence in all 3 of those regional m
componenttext: On the question on Shanghai, I mean, obviously, we look at China. Typically, everybody looks at it as one market. But really, of course, it's 3 markets, it's the north and it's the south and it's Shanghai, and we have presence in all 3 of those regional markets. Shanghai is the biggest market for us. I think it's about 50% to 60% of our total China business. Capacity is up in the Shanghai market in '16, quite a lot. I think what we're seeing there, and we've talked about that as we expected yields to be down moderately, and that's certainly true. And in Shanghai, that's what we're seeing, it's a little bit towards the lower end of the range that we expected.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski of Stifel.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question, I guess, if you go back to -- if I look at your commentary from the fourth quarter about your book load position for non-China itineraries, it seems like, based on your commentary today, those itineraries have gotten a good bit better.
componenttext: So first question, I guess, if you go back to -- if I look at your commentary from the fourth quarter about your book load position for non-China itineraries, it seems like, based on your commentary today, those itineraries have gotten a good bit better. Is that a pretty fair statement?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. I think that's -- the booking environment. So first, just to kind of teeing up is 2/3 of our capacity growth this year is going into China, which is a much closer-in booking environment. So the year-over-year comp is a little bit more challeng
componenttext: Yes, Steve. I think that's -- the booking environment. So first, just to kind of teeing up is 2/3 of our capacity growth this year is going into China, which is a much closer-in booking environment. So the year-over-year comp is a little bit more challenging because you have more of a closer-in environment in your mix. When you take that out, as you said, the strong -- even going into the fourth quarter call as well as what we've seen through WAVE, we have seen strength and we are in a very good book position on both load factor and APD basis.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steven, it's Richard, if I could just one comment on that. I think it's important to understand that we have a fair amount of flexibility in terms of managing that to the level that we want it to be. And last year and this year, we really had record l
componenttext: And Steven, it's Richard, if I could just one comment on that. I think it's important to understand that we have a fair amount of flexibility in terms of managing that to the level that we want it to be. And last year and this year, we really had record levels of capacity booked at this time and at the end of last year. And as a practical matter, we probably don't want to have much more than that. And so that's a revenue management question. A lot depends on how we're managing our price integrity program, how we expect bookings to be in the later period. So it's not only an indicator of how strong demand is, it's also something that we manage to get to a level that we want. So going forward, I would really expect us to be looking for higher levels of capacity booked than we've been seeing over last year and this year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate the commentary. And then second question, I don't know if you'll be able to answer this. But in terms of the Easter shift and Holy Week, how much -- I don't know if there's a way to quantify how much that benefited 1Q and then how much is
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate the commentary. And then second question, I don't know if you'll be able to answer this. But in terms of the Easter shift and Holy Week, how much -- I don't know if there's a way to quantify how much that benefited 1Q and then how much is it taking out of 2Q in terms of yields?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would. It's approximately 20 to 30 basis points that would swap from one quarter to another. And also, the strength that happened in the first quarter was really across the entire quarter. It wasn't necessarily isolated to one, this Holy Week saili
componenttext: Yes, I would. It's approximately 20 to 30 basis points that would swap from one quarter to another. And also, the strength that happened in the first quarter was really across the entire quarter. It wasn't necessarily isolated to one, this Holy Week sailings. So I think that's something else that I wanted to point out, that it was close-in strength for really all North American products during that quarter.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix of Barclays.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, as we think about the second half, I know this isn't necessarily a time when you give guidance for the third quarter but just given some of the misunderstandings about the second quarter, I was wondering if you could help us understand the cadence
componenttext: Jason, as we think about the second half, I know this isn't necessarily a time when you give guidance for the third quarter but just given some of the misunderstandings about the second quarter, I was wondering if you could help us understand the cadence of the quarters, for third and fourth quarter? Because I think if you look at the consensus now, it looks like it's kind of evenly split. And then for your yield guidance for the remainder of the year, how much of that is coming from your new ships and how much is coming from the core?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So cadence-wise, as it relates to Q3 and Q4 and I think taking into account some of our commentary around the Med, I would -- you guys should consider that Q4 should be higher than Q3 as it relates to the cadence. I also take into account that we're
componenttext: Okay. So cadence-wise, as it relates to Q3 and Q4 and I think taking into account some of our commentary around the Med, I would -- you guys should consider that Q4 should be higher than Q3 as it relates to the cadence. I also take into account that we're going to have much more Caribbean product mix in the fourth quarter and we talked about the strength of North American market and the book position that's relative to that. As it relates to the core, I would say the majority of the yield growth what -- I would say majority meaning greater than 50% of the yield growth -- is coming from the new hardware that's coming online in the back half of the year. And I do want to stress the back half of the year because the Ovation is now in our environment and Harmony will be in a couple of weeks. Those ships do take some time to ramp up and also reposition.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the fourth quarter sounds like normally, it's seasonally not stronger than the third. But just given what's going on now, you're -- that's what we should see?
componenttext: Okay. So the fourth quarter sounds like normally, it's seasonally not stronger than the third. But just given what's going on now, you're -- that's what we should see?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my next question for Michael on China, and this is a bigger-picture question. But I think almost every investor meeting I have, I get asked this question, so I think it's worth addressing. I was just wondering if for a moment you could talk
componenttext: Okay. And then my next question for Michael on China, and this is a bigger-picture question. But I think almost every investor meeting I have, I get asked this question, so I think it's worth addressing. I was just wondering if for a moment you could talk about the company's commitment to region and the industry's commitment to the region because there is a lot of investor concern that if pricing doesn't remain its premiums [ph] or if pricing comes down, we all know that [ph] there's supply coming on, will the cruise lines back off in their commitment to the region? And ultimately, could it affect the supply-demand balance of the industry facing the rest -- today elsewhere? So I was just wondering if you could talk about how you're thinking about the China investment. And is there a realistic scenario where that commitment changes?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a great question. We've been in the China market now for nearly 9 years, and we've been investing in the market, building distribution, building our sales presence, building our relationships and more importantly, building the brand and
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a great question. We've been in the China market now for nearly 9 years, and we've been investing in the market, building distribution, building our sales presence, building our relationships and more importantly, building the brand and building a good customer base. And I think as we said previously, we've done very well in the market in terms of being the recipient of the Best Cruise Line for 8 years in a row, the recipient of the Best Premium Cruise Line. So we've done a lot of work in building the brand. I think there's this question about supply and demand and then, of course, distribution. When you look at supply, obviously, we tend to get at times anxious because more capacity is coming into the market. But I think really the question is how much demand is in the marketplace. What we see, if you look at just the sheer size of the outbound market in China, it's the largest outbound market in the world and it's been growing at an incredible rate. Cruise as part of that outbound market is really quite tiny, it's relatively small. We believe that the opportunity for cruise is quite significant in terms of the long-term development, and that's why we've been in the market for 9 years. So we're quite optimistic about the future of China as a marketplace. And I think we've been quite careful and strategic about the decisions that we've made. I think when we introduced Quantum last year, that was really -- proved to be a successful decision. Customers come into the travel agents and request Quantum, request Ovation and request Royal Caribbean. So our commitment is quite strong to the development of China in the future as a marketplace.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you think about your profitability there, what you've said before is on a per passenger cruise day basis higher than the rest of your regions. When you think about the profitability line with -- aligned with the premiums that you're seeing now, whe
componenttext: And as you think about your profitability there, what you've said before is on a per passenger cruise day basis higher than the rest of your regions. When you think about the profitability line with -- aligned with the premiums that you're seeing now, where would that breakeven level be?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think I could answer that question specifically. I think it's true that China continues to trade at the high end of the ticket yield range and deliver high onboard revenue yields. And our Chinese sourcing delivers high profit and returns acr
componenttext: Well, I don't think I could answer that question specifically. I think it's true that China continues to trade at the high end of the ticket yield range and deliver high onboard revenue yields. And our Chinese sourcing delivers high profit and returns across -- against all of the global markets. So we feel that, that opportunity is very good.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next version comes from the line of Harry Curtis of Nomura.
componenttext: Your next version comes from the line of Harry Curtis of Nomura.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been some discussion about the positive impact that we're seeing from the net effect of FX and fuel, but to what degree are the results this year, particularly the costs, somewhat more elevated than they're going to be next year? You're being pena
componenttext: There's been some discussion about the positive impact that we're seeing from the net effect of FX and fuel, but to what degree are the results this year, particularly the costs, somewhat more elevated than they're going to be next year? You're being penalized because of the 50-plus-day shift of Ovation and also the delay of Empress. To what degree is there -- are there higher costs that you're just not going to see next year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the cost side, as we talked about over the long run here, we are managing these costs, I think, in a very effective way. And it's certainly a factor in our progress towards the Double-Double target. I don't think that there are specific one-off
componenttext: I think on the cost side, as we talked about over the long run here, we are managing these costs, I think, in a very effective way. And it's certainly a factor in our progress towards the Double-Double target. I don't think that there are specific one-off costs in this year that are -- that exist. I think that most of the cost growth that you're seeing relates to things -- as an example, would be like the Internet. Putting VOOM or Xcelerate on our ships, there's a cost to that. Improving our footprint, which we will continue to do in China, there's a cost to that. So I don't think that there's something that is specific to this year. I think it's just more in general that this is investment cost need to grow our business. If you look at over the past 3 years, our cost on average have been basically flat, and I think that's been pretty strong result. But I think going forward, there are going to be costs that we have to manage, for example, like improving marketing in order to improve yield.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moving on to the second question. The -- with no new ship deliveries next year, what's a reasonable level of cash that should be returned or could be returned to shareholders next year?
componenttext: Moving on to the second question. The -- with no new ship deliveries next year, what's a reasonable level of cash that should be returned or could be returned to shareholders next year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think obviously, capital return is something that will be a discussion with our board. We clearly want to be in a position to balance investing in our growth, which is pretty well planned, be in investment-grade credit and then providing capital re
componenttext: Yes. I think obviously, capital return is something that will be a discussion with our board. We clearly want to be in a position to balance investing in our growth, which is pretty well planned, be in investment-grade credit and then providing capital returns to our shareholders. And I think for us, we want to get through the authorization, the $500 million authorization that we still have $50 million left to do, and I'm sure we will address that in the future as those decisions are taken.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's reasonable to think that you're not going to stop at the $50 million left?
componenttext: So it's reasonable to think that you're not going to stop at the $50 million left?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say that it's reasonable to think that our management team and our board will be considering that dividends and share buybacks are mechanisms to return capital to shareholders.
componenttext: I would say that it's reasonable to think that our management team and our board will be considering that dividends and share buybacks are mechanisms to return capital to shareholders.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder of Wells Fargo.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to circle back to China here. Adam, Jason or Richard, can you just sort of give us your color on what your net yield range is for China on a year-over-year? And maybe break that down into the like-for-like itineraries versus the impact of more year
componenttext: I want to circle back to China here. Adam, Jason or Richard, can you just sort of give us your color on what your net yield range is for China on a year-over-year? And maybe break that down into the like-for-like itineraries versus the impact of more year-round capacity and thirdly, adding shoulder periods which pull that average down?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we don't give specific guidance on our net yields in the market. But as Michael commented, it is certainly a significant premium to our fleet average as well as a significant premium to the marketplace there today. We also commented on the fourth quart
componenttext: So we don't give specific guidance on our net yields in the market. But as Michael commented, it is certainly a significant premium to our fleet average as well as a significant premium to the marketplace there today. We also commented on the fourth quarter call that we expected yields to be down in China and we still expect that. And as Michael commented, I think the only kind of pressure point has been Shanghai where there's been a lot of capacity in place. But I think that people should look at China as well as just Asia in total. It's a market that the average yield is higher than the average. And as we add more capacity in, that improves our revenue and that improves our profitability. And that's how you should see us continuing our strategy.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then that profitability, Jason, again, to clarify from prior question, is given that on the yield side, is it higher than the balance of the world? Would you -- is that fair to assume?
componenttext: And then that profitability, Jason, again, to clarify from prior question, is given that on the yield side, is it higher than the balance of the world? Would you -- is that fair to assume?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On a return perspective?
componenttext: On a return perspective?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, it's -- both on yield and on returns, it's certainly higher than the average.
componenttext: Yes. No, it's -- both on yield and on returns, it's certainly higher than the average.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then could you expand on your comments about connecting more directly with the Chinese consumer? And then lastly, how should we think about the cadence of the new ships from Mein Schiff coming in and the impact there on the income from TUI in pa
componenttext: Okay. And then could you expand on your comments about connecting more directly with the Chinese consumer? And then lastly, how should we think about the cadence of the new ships from Mein Schiff coming in and the impact there on the income from TUI in particular below the line?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can talk about how we've been connecting with the customer in China. One of the things that we've been doing is investing more in consumer marketing, direct to customer. So for example, this year, we launched a television campaign in Tianjin and Shangha
componenttext: I can talk about how we've been connecting with the customer in China. One of the things that we've been doing is investing more in consumer marketing, direct to customer. So for example, this year, we launched a television campaign in Tianjin and Shanghai with dedicated Chinese TV commercials and what have you, and we've been spending more time just talking directly to the consumer. And of course, over time, we've literally built up a loyal database of customers who've sailed with us and they're great advocates for the brand and of course, they talk about Royal Caribbean in the marketplace. So it's a gradual process and it's a process we've been engaged in for some time and we'll continue to invest in.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then TUI?
componenttext: And then TUI?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, Tim. What was the question on TUI?
componenttext: Sorry, Tim. What was the question on TUI?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just how should we think about the cadence of the Mein Schiff 5 and then Mein Schiff 6? As those come into the flow here, how should we think about that impacting that equity income line?
componenttext: Just how should we think about the cadence of the Mein Schiff 5 and then Mein Schiff 6? As those come into the flow here, how should we think about that impacting that equity income line?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we do now break out that profitability line or equity pickup line in our filing and I think that -- I think it's reasonable to consider that, that trend change year-over-year will continue as the new ships come onboard.
componenttext: Well, I think that we do now break out that profitability line or equity pickup line in our filing and I think that -- I think it's reasonable to consider that, that trend change year-over-year will continue as the new ships come onboard.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley of UBS.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to get [ph] your full year yield guidance. It's not up by as much as the outperformance in Q1. Is that -- should we think about that more as just -- it's within the range of being conservative with rounding? [ph] Or is it -- do you have a slightly mo
componenttext: Just to get [ph] your full year yield guidance. It's not up by as much as the outperformance in Q1. Is that -- should we think about that more as just -- it's within the range of being conservative with rounding? [ph] Or is it -- do you have a slightly more conservative view of the rest of the year because of your comments about the Med? And I'm just thinking about the -- it sounded like Q2, a little lower than consensus, but I would think the Med would be more of a Q3 impacting Q2, so just maybe how to think about that?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Robin, to that point, our -- the increase in our yield guidance for the year, which gives a midpoint of 3.25%, a lot of that is a read-through from Q1. And then on from Q2 to Q4, yes, we are taking a -- I wouldn't say it's more consecutive posture
componenttext: Yes. So Robin, to that point, our -- the increase in our yield guidance for the year, which gives a midpoint of 3.25%, a lot of that is a read-through from Q1. And then on from Q2 to Q4, yes, we are taking a -- I wouldn't say it's more consecutive posture but a more realistic posture as it relates to the Mediterranean. And so our expectation is our yields are going to be lower. It is disproportional in Q2 for a few reasons, one of which is the ships are now repositioning or have repositioned to Europe, so they do have May sailings and June sailings. And as I talk about the lull that we saw after the recent geopolitical events, that there is -- there was a need to do some price stimulation on some of the more -- the closer-in bookings that related to the Med in which that will really occur with the North American consumer.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But then you're comfortable with Q3 because after that sort of lull post Brussels, in other words, you've seen a pick up since then for the Med sailings later in the [indiscernible]?
componenttext: But then you're comfortable with Q3 because after that sort of lull post Brussels, in other words, you've seen a pick up since then for the Med sailings later in the [indiscernible]?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, it's picked up. It's -- actually, our load factors are higher. As I commented in my remarks that -- but we're sourcing more guests from Europe. In Europe, European consumers do spend a little bit less on ticket and certainly less on onboard, and
componenttext: Yes. No, it's picked up. It's -- actually, our load factors are higher. As I commented in my remarks that -- but we're sourcing more guests from Europe. In Europe, European consumers do spend a little bit less on ticket and certainly less on onboard, and that does weigh in on both Q2 and Q3 yields.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then lastly just a quick clarification, you mentioned sales in China, higher in the last 3 months. Is that just volume higher? Or did you mean actually like load higher like capacity adjusted volumes higher?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then lastly just a quick clarification, you mentioned sales in China, higher in the last 3 months. Is that just volume higher? Or did you mean actually like load higher like capacity adjusted volumes higher?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's volume but it -- but the common hold for capacity adjusted.
componenttext: It's volume but it -- but the common hold for capacity adjusted.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Kent of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Kent of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. What percentage of your European summer sailings are typically U.S. sourced? And how has that changed this year? I'm not sure if you have addressed it yet but the Empress of the Seas delay, what's causing that?
componenttext: Two questions. What percentage of your European summer sailings are typically U.S. sourced? And how has that changed this year? I'm not sure if you have addressed it yet but the Empress of the Seas delay, what's causing that?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, I think Jason's looking up the numbers on the European sourcing. I can talk a little about Empress of the Seas. We brought Empress back from Pullmantur. It has been over with Pullmantur for approximately 9 years. We obviously had an expectation. W
componenttext: Steven, I think Jason's looking up the numbers on the European sourcing. I can talk a little about Empress of the Seas. We brought Empress back from Pullmantur. It has been over with Pullmantur for approximately 9 years. We obviously had an expectation. We were going to do a certain amount of work with the ship. And as we started the work, we realized that we simply had more work to do. We wanted to make sure that we brought the ship up to the standard that our customers are used to with Royal Caribbean International, and a lot of that work required just more time to complete it. So we had to extend the work time, and I think now we've got the ship scheduled to come back into operation at the end of May.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this was customer-facing stuff rather than engineering?
componenttext: So this was customer-facing stuff rather than engineering?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it was related to customer experience. And Steve, on the European sourcing side, for European probably it's about 2/3 of our guests for European sailings coming from Europe. And this year, it will be 3 or 4 percentage points higher as we've shifted th
componenttext: No, it was related to customer experience. And Steve, on the European sourcing side, for European probably it's about 2/3 of our guests for European sailings coming from Europe. And this year, it will be 3 or 4 percentage points higher as we've shifted that sourcing.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Blair.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, can you give us, for the Mediterranean, what your capacity is over the spring and summer versus last year?
componenttext: Jason, can you give us, for the Mediterranean, what your capacity is over the spring and summer versus last year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Med capacity, the year-over-year is basically flat. It's up about 1% for us year-over-year.
componenttext: Yes. Med capacity, the year-over-year is basically flat. It's up about 1% for us year-over-year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to clarify on Robin's question earlier. The lull that you saw for North American demand, that is recovered? I was not sure if you were saying you recovered it just with the European sourcing. But have you seen the North American custom
componenttext: Okay. And then just to clarify on Robin's question earlier. The lull that you saw for North American demand, that is recovered? I was not sure if you were saying you recovered it just with the European sourcing. But have you seen the North American customer come back to more normalized kind of booking cadence for the Med?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, the lull is just overall recovery in terms of load factor. As Michael commented before, the North American consumer, they were still very interested in Europe, but some of that interest has shifted to the North American products where we've seen
componenttext: Yes. No, the lull is just overall recovery in terms of load factor. As Michael commented before, the North American consumer, they were still very interested in Europe, but some of that interest has shifted to the North American products where we've seen a lot of strength.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon of Berenberg.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon of Berenberg.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, please. I was just -- I'm interested on VOOM. I was just wondering how many ships you now have are connected? And how will that change over this year and how has it been changing? And also, could you just give us a flavor for how yo
componenttext: A couple of questions, please. I was just -- I'm interested on VOOM. I was just wondering how many ships you now have are connected? And how will that change over this year and how has it been changing? And also, could you just give us a flavor for how you think about your guidance? Clearly, the close-in bookings and the onboard spend was extremely strong in the quarter. But how do you think for that when you're putting together your guidances? Is the assumption based on what you're seeing in booking trends at the point in time or do you try and be more dynamic about it?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. I can answer the question with regards to VOOM. On May 1, literally, every single ship in the Royal Caribbean International fleet will have VOOM onboard. So we're literally now implementing it ship by ship. I can't recall how many ships have
componenttext: This is Mike. I can answer the question with regards to VOOM. On May 1, literally, every single ship in the Royal Caribbean International fleet will have VOOM onboard. So we're literally now implementing it ship by ship. I can't recall how many ships have it currently, but literally by -- in a few days, every single ship will have it.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And sort of what pace was that, sorry, Michael? Was that -- how many ships -- I mean, is that evenly spread over the sort of last 12 to 18 months?
componenttext: And sort of what pace was that, sorry, Michael? Was that -- how many ships -- I mean, is that evenly spread over the sort of last 12 to 18 months?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I can't recall, Stuart, how many ships we had about a couple of months ago. This has literally happened over about a 90- to 100-day -- 120-day period that we've implemented the entire fleet, so it's literally gone from 5, 6, 7 ships to 23, 24 ships
componenttext: The -- I can't recall, Stuart, how many ships we had about a couple of months ago. This has literally happened over about a 90- to 100-day -- 120-day period that we've implemented the entire fleet, so it's literally gone from 5, 6, 7 ships to 23, 24 ships over the past 90 days.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Stuart as it relates to how we think about guidance, certainly, it's -- our guidance is really a reflection of what we're seeing in the booking environment prior to the call and certainly, if we've seen patterns on close-in, we would certainly be
componenttext: And then Stuart as it relates to how we think about guidance, certainly, it's -- our guidance is really a reflection of what we're seeing in the booking environment prior to the call and certainly, if we've seen patterns on close-in, we would certainly be taking that to account in our guidance. There was particular strength in the first quarter from the North American consumer for the Caribbean. And on the onboard, as we continued to roll out VOOM, as Michael indicated or Xcelerate on Celebrity, those are new things we're introducing that -- not all the time, you create the results that we saw as we introduce new things. But clearly, that worked well for us in the first quarter.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vince Ciepiel of Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vince Ciepiel of Cleveland Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on this new pricing policy. On a prior call, you mentioned there'd be some residual impact in 2016, maybe some cabins going empty. Could you comment on how you've seen this trend year-to-date? I think you also mentioned that by 2017, the
componenttext: I had a question on this new pricing policy. On a prior call, you mentioned there'd be some residual impact in 2016, maybe some cabins going empty. Could you comment on how you've seen this trend year-to-date? I think you also mentioned that by 2017, the impact would be positive. Do you think you're still tracking in line with the target?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's still playing out pretty much as we expected. We do think that there is some impact on capacity or on occupancy in 2016. But as we said, we don't think the effect has been huge, and we think that by 2017, it will be positive. So nothing'
componenttext: Yes, I think it's still playing out pretty much as we expected. We do think that there is some impact on capacity or on occupancy in 2016. But as we said, we don't think the effect has been huge, and we think that by 2017, it will be positive. So nothing's changed in our perspective as to how that would play out.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then secondly, on net cruise costs, I know you guys have mentioned that tend to be a little lumpy on a quarterly basis. But I think there was the thought that the fourth quarter would be lower and the guidance seems to imply the second half may
componenttext: Great. And then secondly, on net cruise costs, I know you guys have mentioned that tend to be a little lumpy on a quarterly basis. But I think there was the thought that the fourth quarter would be lower and the guidance seems to imply the second half maybe turns negative year-over-year. So if you could just comment on the quarterly cadence 3Q versus 4Q in terms of net cruise costs?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think cost for the third quarter will be lower than they are in the fourth quarter should be the expectation. What drives that is obviously, there's the new capacity coming online, but also we don't have any dry dock days in the third quarter an
componenttext: Yes. So I think cost for the third quarter will be lower than they are in the fourth quarter should be the expectation. What drives that is obviously, there's the new capacity coming online, but also we don't have any dry dock days in the third quarter and last year, we did. And so that's make that year-over-year comp more achievable. So that should be how you kind of think about the cadence for the back half of the year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jaime Katz of Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jaime Katz of Morningstar.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm actually curious about some of the smaller brands, first, the performance of Pullmantur over the last few months in light of the Mediterranean environment. And then I think it's been sometime since we've heard anything about the relationship with Ctri
componenttext: I'm actually curious about some of the smaller brands, first, the performance of Pullmantur over the last few months in light of the Mediterranean environment. And then I think it's been sometime since we've heard anything about the relationship with Ctrip. So I'm curious if we can learn more about any of the read-throughs that you've gotten from them about the Chinese consumer or anything that's changed with that relationship?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll comment on Pullmantur. As you know, we did take a change in strategy. We decided that it would be better to pull back a bit and focus on the Spanish and French markets. That actually seems to be doing well. And actually, Pullmantur ironically i
componenttext: Sure. I'll comment on Pullmantur. As you know, we did take a change in strategy. We decided that it would be better to pull back a bit and focus on the Spanish and French markets. That actually seems to be doing well. And actually, Pullmantur ironically is -- has had some of the more positive variances at -- in our company. At the same time, as I always said publicly, we periodically look at strategic opportunities, and we would do that for any of our enterprises. But we'll see where that takes us. But right now, ironically, Spain, in particular, is proving itself to be turning around quite strongly. Now it's doing so from a very low base, but it does appear to be doing so. And so I think we're feeling better about that market than we have in a long time. I'll ask Adam to talk on the Ctrip.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ctrip is our partner in SkySea, and we are very, very pleased to be in partnership with them. They're an excellent company, forward looking, very much a fundamental part of the growing Chinese travel market and good partners, we think, for the long ter
componenttext: So Ctrip is our partner in SkySea, and we are very, very pleased to be in partnership with them. They're an excellent company, forward looking, very much a fundamental part of the growing Chinese travel market and good partners, we think, for the long term. SkySea, the name of the cruise line that is our venture with Ctrip, will be coming up on its first anniversary in about 3 weeks. And so she's a very, very young cruise line with one ship and doesn't have the kind of presence yet on the Chinese market that would even compare to Royal Caribbean International, as Michael has been discussing. So we hope to build a different profile of clients, a client that understands that this is a primarily Chinese-owned venture and will offer certain opportunities, whether it's through technology or in the guest experience that will be differentiating in the marketplace but it's very early days still. We'll have to see how the second season goes and we hope to be able to grow SkySea in the future.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Assia Georgieva of Infinity Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Assia Georgieva of Infinity Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of quick questions. So in terms of the European-sourced passengers, they tend to book closer-in than the North American passenger. Do you think that there still may be an opportunity in May, in June to where that low post Brussels kind of -
componenttext: I had a couple of quick questions. So in terms of the European-sourced passengers, they tend to book closer-in than the North American passenger. Do you think that there still may be an opportunity in May, in June to where that low post Brussels kind of -- gets taken away from people's minds and we might see some close-in pickup?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the European markets have been quite good. So the lull was more impacted the North American customer than it impacted the European customer. European sourcing has been pretty good. So -- and there is kind of a transition point that occurs around May,
componenttext: Yes, the European markets have been quite good. So the lull was more impacted the North American customer than it impacted the European customer. European sourcing has been pretty good. So -- and there is kind of a transition point that occurs around May, June in terms of a natural shift between demand, between the North American market and the European market. As you've pointed out, it's more of a light booking market for the European. So it's going to pick up anyway out of the European markets, but the European markets are in pretty good condition.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Richard, quick question for you. I think in your opening remarks, you mentioned $6.78 EPS target for 2017. I may have missed something. But somehow, I had a $7 figure stuck in my mind.
componenttext: Okay. And Richard, quick question for you. I think in your opening remarks, you mentioned $6.78 EPS target for 2017. I may have missed something. But somehow, I had a $7 figure stuck in my mind.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I didn't actually -- maybe I should have been clearer, that is the Double-Double number. So our EPS in 2000 or let's see, in 2014, our adjusted EPS was $3.39 and our Double-Double target is simply double that. And if my math is right and I sure hope
componenttext: Yes. I didn't actually -- maybe I should have been clearer, that is the Double-Double number. So our EPS in 2000 or let's see, in 2014, our adjusted EPS was $3.39 and our Double-Double target is simply double that. And if my math is right and I sure hope it is, that's $6.78. I think people may have sort of been rounding that to $7, and I know some people think that we're doing better than the Double-Double. But we set out the Double-Double, it was an aggressive target when we set it out. The objective was to mobilize the people in the company to that goal. It served that purpose very well. And obviously, if we do better than the $6.78, that would be terrific, too. So I don't think we've -- we're not giving guidance for 2017, but that is literally the target that we've set a year or 2 ago when we set those targets.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jared Shojaian of Wolfe Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow up on that yield and discounting commentary. I know last year, you talked pretty regularly about how eliminating these last-minute discounts was a headwind. And just judging by the close-in strengths you're seeing right now, it looks l
componenttext: Just want to follow up on that yield and discounting commentary. I know last year, you talked pretty regularly about how eliminating these last-minute discounts was a headwind. And just judging by the close-in strengths you're seeing right now, it looks like it's a nice tailwind here in 2016. So can you quantify how much of your yield guidance for the remainder of the year is attributable to any of these tailwinds? And I'm specifically trying to think about this in the context of 2017. Is there any reason why the yields we're seeing this year can't be repeated again next year? Anything you can share on early 2017 bookings yields would be helpful.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Jared, as it relates to '17, we'll be addressing that as we move into future quarters because it's really kind of too early to provide any kind of forecast on things going forward. But I would say that the impact we talk about as it relates to th
componenttext: Okay. So Jared, as it relates to '17, we'll be addressing that as we move into future quarters because it's really kind of too early to provide any kind of forecast on things going forward. But I would say that the impact we talk about as it relates to the price improvement program, those are just quantifiable things, for example, number of cabins that go empty. What's not quantifiable is really us continuing to build a better book of business at higher load factors, higher rates and a window that keeps extending. And so in that is -- are more quality bookings and some of that is because of the reconditioning of the consumer, knowing that we're not going to be discounting close-in. Those benefits are very difficult to measure. But we do think, on a volume perspective, that, that kind of turns itself around into next year. And as we've always done in the past, we'll give color on '17 as we move more towards the back half of the year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, what are your expectations for timing on Cuba? Caribbean obviously has been very strong this past fourth and first quarter. And I think some people are wondering how you can drive incremental yield off some of these comps. S
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, what are your expectations for timing on Cuba? Caribbean obviously has been very strong this past fourth and first quarter. And I think some people are wondering how you can drive incremental yield off some of these comps. So do you think Cuba could be that source of incremental yield growth as we head into 1Q '17? Or is it too soon to be talking about it?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jared, it's Adam. So it's -- we have a keen desire, I think Michael might have expressed this before, to take our guests to Cuba. Obviously, if you think about what we've been doing since 1970, our ships keep cruising on a giant circle around Cuba without
componenttext: Jared, it's Adam. So it's -- we have a keen desire, I think Michael might have expressed this before, to take our guests to Cuba. Obviously, if you think about what we've been doing since 1970, our ships keep cruising on a giant circle around Cuba without going there. And we're excited about it. But this is a dialogue that continues with the Cuban government, and the timing of permission to go is unclear, although we're optimistic. And so it's hard to predict when any involvement in Cuba would have become part of our business. And as we tried to express on previous dialogues, Cuba's infrastructure is very, very limited in terms of the overall amount of capacity that it can take. If it develops well over the years coming, eventually, it probably can become one of the mainstay marquee Caribbean regions, but that's a long way off. So we hope to be there in the short term, but it would be on a fairly limited presence.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think we've made it pretty clear that we don't think, even when it is operational, it'll be a major part of our business. So I wouldn't have thought that, that per se, looked at in isolation, would be a driver. However, I think -- 2 things. It
componenttext: Yes. And I think we've made it pretty clear that we don't think, even when it is operational, it'll be a major part of our business. So I wouldn't have thought that, that per se, looked at in isolation, would be a driver. However, I think -- 2 things. It actually will help general yields in the area because I think it does raise interest. The publicity about Cuba, the discussions about Cuba raises interest in Caribbean cruising. The other thing is I want to dispel any notion that -- where we think that the yield improvement that we're getting today is particularly high. We've got some terrific new vessels, we've got really very strong market position of our brands, of our operations. So we think the big driver, and we think it will continue -- it has been a driver and we think will be a driver -- is actually the -- how powerful our brands are doing in the marketplace.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Hardiman of Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Hardiman of Wedbush Securities.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just, and you may have already answered this but I want to be 100% clear on sort of the China dynamic. Obviously, yields for China itself are down versus last year. But Chinese yields are significantly higher than your average. Net-net, is China helpin
componenttext: So just, and you may have already answered this but I want to be 100% clear on sort of the China dynamic. Obviously, yields for China itself are down versus last year. But Chinese yields are significantly higher than your average. Net-net, is China helping your yields this year? And as I think about last year, I know you're not giving the 2017 guidance, but should we expect a similar impact to overall yields next year? I think there's some fear among investors that there's a delayed impact based on the way that the charter process works and that we still haven't felt all the fallout from the -- from some of the charters losing money on some of the cruises last year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael. Yes, I think some of the charters lost money for a period of time in '15 because of the South Korea MERS and the typhoons. But sometimes I think we forget that those very same charters made a lot of money over the past 8 years and continue t
componenttext: It's Michael. Yes, I think some of the charters lost money for a period of time in '15 because of the South Korea MERS and the typhoons. But sometimes I think we forget that those very same charters made a lot of money over the past 8 years and continue to make money and they're chartering space as they previously had done. So I think it was a glitch that impacted some of the charters during that period and I think a lot of them now have recovered from that. Certainly, the China business is very positive for our overall business. And as I think we've already commented it, high-yielding, high-yielding market and it contributes nicely to our overall yield that's above average. So when we look into '17, for example, I think Richard had mentioned that growth for the industry in '17 is closer to 50% versus the close to 100% over the past few years. So capacity is slightly -- overall growth is slowing a little bit in '17. For Royal Caribbean International, we've already announced our deployment for '17. And overall, I think we're up about 8% or 9% in the market in '17.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just last question for me. On the other income line, there's been a lot of moving parts there. I think if you add back the Pullmantur accounting, it was about $20 million positive. Any way you can give us guidance on that line for the full
componenttext: Great. And then just last question for me. On the other income line, there's been a lot of moving parts there. I think if you add back the Pullmantur accounting, it was about $20 million positive. Any way you can give us guidance on that line for the full year and maybe how to think about the puts and the takes there?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think that if you were to take our yield and cost, the differential is the other income line. And the element of the other income line that really changes outside of it and affecting us and types of things is the improvement in our equity inv
componenttext:
Yes. Well, I think that if you were to take our yield and cost, the differential is the other income line. And the element of the other income line that really changes outside of it and affecting us and types of things is the improvement in our equity investments. So I think if you look at the year-over-year growth, especially in the back half of the year, before we disclose in our filing for TUI, that's a good proxy in -- to think about how other income and expense will grow for the back half of the year. Because if you take into account the interest and you take into account TUI, that should get you pretty close.
Great. Thank you for your assistance, Laurie, with the call today, and we thank you all for your participation and interest in the company. Carol will be available for any follow-up you might have today, and I wish you all a very great day.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
