componenttextpreview: Sure, Jared. So the impact from the delay of deployment was about $0.06 or $0.07 for the fourth quarter. Outside of that, there's small little puts and takes that make up the balance but it's very immaterial.
componenttext: Sure, Jared. So the impact from the delay of deployment was about $0.06 or $0.07 for the fourth quarter. Outside of that, there's small little puts and takes that make up the balance but it's very immaterial.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, obviously there's been a lot of concern about just the promotional environment, particularly in the Caribbean. Can you expand on that and just what you're seeing right now and if you feel the need to be more -- a little bit more pro
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, obviously there's been a lot of concern about just the promotional environment, particularly in the Caribbean. Can you expand on that and just what you're seeing right now and if you feel the need to be more -- a little bit more promotional right now just because of some of the incremental capacity or just how you're thinking about that?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's -- sorry, Jared, it's Michael. yes, We're feeling pretty good about the Caribbean. Some things looking good, especially on volume and rate with the capacity increase and '16 shaping up pretty well. It looks very typical in terms of what we're
componenttext: David, it's -- sorry, Jared, it's Michael. yes, We're feeling pretty good about the Caribbean. Some things looking good, especially on volume and rate with the capacity increase and '16 shaping up pretty well. It looks very typical in terms of what we're seeing with booking patterns in Q4 as we've seen in previous years. So everything's looking quite normal. Obviously, promotional activity ebbs and flows. We had Hurricane Matthew blowing through the week before last, so we had about a week of drop in bookings which is inevitable as it moves its way up the East Coast. And then I think we did and others certainly tried to stimulate the demand by putting in some promotional activity, which then the response was very good. We had a promotion last week, which was the second-best performing promotion in the brand's history.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Beckel with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Beckel with Bernstein Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could -- maybe a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up to
componenttext: I was wondering if you could -- maybe a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up to that, what are some of the more significant levers on cost you can pull if yields do come in lighter than expected?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about some of the chunki
componenttext: We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about some of the chunkier things that we've been doing on the cost side. And really, over the past year or so, a lot of this is thousands [ph] of little things that we do to become more efficient across our business. There are always small levers to pull, to try to write yourself if there is yield challenges, but there is nothing specific that I would call out. But I think -- I would leave this point by saying that I think we've shown, over the past several years, management's commitment to cost control and try to become more efficient year-over-year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So
componenttext: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So the yield -- the risk of continued yield pressures in China, supply growth in the Caribbean and then also FX fuel headwinds for next year. So regarding Asia Pacific, I think you said that in China -- you said that your book position is -- China's ahead of -- you're ahead of in-load, so I was just wondering if for a moment you could touch upon maybe how you -- if you think where yields could come out next year? If you think you could see yield pressure again in China, and then also your confidence level of growing yields in the Caribbean? And then, if there's any way -- I mean, I think a lot of people are doing the math based on where FX and fuel is today to kind of calculate where that might impact next year, so if you could touch upon that as well.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this poin
componenttext: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this point in the year, we have pretty good visibility into the first quarter, it's been encouraging and hopefully those trends continue on as that product books further out here over time. And then when we talk about the Caribbean, and I would also include Europe in there, at this point in time in the year, a lot of that is driven by the North American consumer. And as I commented in my remarks that we have seen very positive trends in both the rate and volume basis for the Caribbean as well as for our European products. And then to answer your question on the currency side, certainly, the strength of the dollar relative to the pound has been challenging. If you want to say, well, what it has kind of been since the last call, it's probably hurt us by about $0.12 to $0.15. So there's -- there are always headwinds in our business that we have to focus on and overcome but that's kind of been the impact since the last time we spoke here in early August.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, just a follow up on some puts and takes for next year because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points will reopened in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management fee as well. So m
componenttext: Okay, just a follow up on some puts and takes for next year because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points will reopened in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management fee as well. So maybe if you could help us understand how the full picture -- the full mathematical picture works for Pullmantur?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates to the demand. So it's a small contributor but it's not something I would specifically call out and build up in the yield.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the Empress because I guess, our impression has been that you're maybe not opening up Empress for new sailings because you were hoping for a new Caribbean itinerary to open up before the end of the year. So I wanted to ask what your
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the Empress because I guess, our impression has been that you're maybe not opening up Empress for new sailings because you were hoping for a new Caribbean itinerary to open up before the end of the year. So I wanted to ask what your expectation. Is it still to potentially that could open up by the end of the year? Or is the idea to keep Empress sort of into Q1 without opening it up for new sailings yet?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously as we continue the deployment for Empress because as you know, Robin, we deployed a ship -- we open up a deployment for a ship about 12 months to 18 months ahead of time. I think we have seen or we have obviously been in conversations about w
componenttext: So obviously as we continue the deployment for Empress because as you know, Robin, we deployed a ship -- we open up a deployment for a ship about 12 months to 18 months ahead of time. I think we have seen or we have obviously been in conversations about what the future deployment of that ship could be and that did not resolve itself in the back half of this year and that's really what cause the impact on Empress because we effectively open up her deployment in August. I think we continue to look for that ship to potentially have some other deployment but I don't think we will be holding back our sailings in the future and we'll deal with it as maybe some of that new deployment comes available.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And just a comment, Robin, it's already open for next year, Empress.

componenttext: For existing Caribbean itineraries?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And for -- my follow-up question, there's been some reports in the Caribbean media that China is limiting some tour package travel to Korea for political reasons and I'm just wondering if you're seeing any kind of impact at all for cruises fr
componenttext: Okay, great. And for -- my follow-up question, there's been some reports in the Caribbean media that China is limiting some tour package travel to Korea for political reasons and I'm just wondering if you're seeing any kind of impact at all for cruises from China calling Korea ports, any impact at all of getting the sense that there's going to be some kind of a limit you're seeing so far for any mainland China visitors going to Korea by cruise?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Robin, it's Michael. We have seen no impact. We think it's very much related to a type of package that's offered that really is all about encouraging Chinese customers to go to Korea specifically for shopping trips and we think it's related to that. S
componenttext: Hi, Robin, it's Michael. We have seen no impact. We think it's very much related to a type of package that's offered that really is all about encouraging Chinese customers to go to Korea specifically for shopping trips and we think it's related to that. So the package is put into the market at incredibly low cost and of course, they bring the customers over and make their revenue from the retail. So we feel as if that's something that's very specifically focused. So we don't -- we have not seen anything and we don't believe there will be any impact to us.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple things. Wanted to revisit the mix shift with the Harmony and the Equinox, Jason, that you called out. Is that going to be yield accretive given Europe traditionally has higher yields than the Caribbean? Just that ships the similar comparison
componenttext: Just a couple things. Wanted to revisit the mix shift with the Harmony and the Equinox, Jason, that you called out. Is that going to be yield accretive given Europe traditionally has higher yields than the Caribbean? Just that ships the similar comparison year-over-year, just a little tour on that, please? And then, you guys had been fairly aggressive towards the high end or above the higher end of your 40% to 60% range in hedging, specially it appeared on quite a bit on oil was in the 30s. Maybe a little bit more color on where your weighted average hedges are looking into '17 and '18? And then, if you continue view as layering on more aggressively or may be sort of back off a little bit on that as you layer out 12 months, 24 months, 36 months?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Tim, the first question as it relates to our Harmony and Equinox. Trends or demand for Harmony has been exceptional and we do expect that Harmony, being here next year for it to be yield accretive. Certainly helps us a lot in the first half of the yea
componenttext: So, Tim, the first question as it relates to our Harmony and Equinox. Trends or demand for Harmony has been exceptional and we do expect that Harmony, being here next year for it to be yield accretive. Certainly helps us a lot in the first half of the year. Equinox in the Eastern Mediterranean and really kind of in the center of a lot of movements we have to make with some of the geopolitical events that were happening. And so we expect the Equinox to be yield accretive to the corporation next year. On the fuel side, in '17, we're hedge about 60%. The average hedge rate there is about $508 and '18, we're 45% hedged and we're about $452 on the average hedge. And we continue to focus on having a hedge program to minimize the volatility within our P&L and we also respect that there's typically an inverse relationship between fuel and currency. We also take in consideration the fuel curve and it has flattened out. And so there's -- earlier last year, we did take advantage and put a little bit more hedging on in '16 and in the outer years but you should expect us to continue to be pretty consistent to the past of that kind of 40% to 60% outside of things. And again, with the goal of minimizing volatility.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my follow up would be related to Europe. You said you've seen very good bookings so far out of North America, given specifically how it books early for Europe. Any color by region? I mean, is it more toward Northern Europe or the Western
componenttext: Okay, great. And my follow up would be related to Europe. You said you've seen very good bookings so far out of North America, given specifically how it books early for Europe. Any color by region? I mean, is it more toward Northern Europe or the Western Med where consolidated into the Med, just any additional color on how the Brits are booking also?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, it's Michael. Europe's looking quite good for '17 when we look at our forward bookings. Obviously, Eastern Med capacity is down versus last year and the year before. We've been aware of that. So it's pretty much all over Europe. So Northern Europe ob
componenttext: Tim, it's Michael. Europe's looking quite good for '17 when we look at our forward bookings. Obviously, Eastern Med capacity is down versus last year and the year before. We've been aware of that. So it's pretty much all over Europe. So Northern Europe obviously is doing quite well and also Western Med, European markets. Typically, a later booking than the American market. The America market seems to be quite well at the moment for Europe. And the British market, surprisingly is quite robust. We were thinking that we would see more of an impact, a little bit of an impact on board spend but nothing really material.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski with Stifel.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to ask a Double-Double question a little bit differently and one of the questions we get a lot from investors is how are you guys going to achieve the Double-Double next year without buying back a significant amount of your stock or getting some
componenttext: So I want to ask a Double-Double question a little bit differently and one of the questions we get a lot from investors is how are you guys going to achieve the Double-Double next year without buying back a significant amount of your stock or getting some massive benefit from Pullmantur? Could you maybe help us think about the bridge to get around or get close to the Double-Double range? Meaning, if you do a midpoint this year of 6, call it, 6.05, from a very high level, how do you get up close that 6.78 or 6.80 number? That would be pretty helpful?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we won't kind of talk about any guidance for next year but really, you need us to continue to show strong cost control and have, modest yield improvement and that gets you most of the way and then obviously, there is some benefit we get from th
componenttext: Obviously, we won't kind of talk about any guidance for next year but really, you need us to continue to show strong cost control and have, modest yield improvement and that gets you most of the way and then obviously, there is some benefit we get from the deconsolidation of Pullmantur but that's really a small amount of that pie.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's Richard here, 1 of the things that we've tried to emphasize for the last 3 or 4 years is we put in place the Double-Double Program with an idea that we want to motivate our team and focus our team on a particular target but it wasn't something
componenttext: Steve, it's Richard here, 1 of the things that we've tried to emphasize for the last 3 or 4 years is we put in place the Double-Double Program with an idea that we want to motivate our team and focus our team on a particular target but it wasn't something, and we said this before, that require heroic efforts. So we do need good cost control. We think we have been showing that. We do need moderate yield improvements. We think we've been showing that. And I think as you look to the Double-Double year, obviously it's a complicated set of all of the things that happened in our business but as we simply look at where we are today and with the moderate kind of yield improvements that we are looking for, we don't think we need to do anything heroic to make the Double-Double and we continue to believe we'll do it.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one more comment, Steve. I think you're just always appreciating the sensitivities because every 1% percent change in yield is about $70 million. And So by just keeping cost managed. Most of that drops to the bottom line and that in itself drives
componenttext: And just one more comment, Steve. I think you're just always appreciating the sensitivities because every 1% percent change in yield is about $70 million. And So by just keeping cost managed. Most of that drops to the bottom line and that in itself drives that difference in earnings.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my second question -- you guys might kill me for asking this but I know we're not even remotely close to 2017 or done with 2017. But have you guys given any thought to what's beyond 2017 and what's beyond the Double-Double? Is it -- looki
componenttext: Okay, great. And my second question -- you guys might kill me for asking this but I know we're not even remotely close to 2017 or done with 2017. But have you guys given any thought to what's beyond 2017 and what's beyond the Double-Double? Is it -- looking back, is this something that you guys are -- obviously have fully embraced it but is there something that potentially could come once this is over? Meaning, another type of program like the Double-Double?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the beauty of having -- Steve, it's a reasonable question and in fact something that we asked ourselves all the time. And I think I included in my comments that the Double-Double is a step on the journey. We, in terms of what comes after Double-Double,
componenttext: So the beauty of having -- Steve, it's a reasonable question and in fact something that we asked ourselves all the time. And I think I included in my comments that the Double-Double is a step on the journey. We, in terms of what comes after Double-Double, I don't know whether it will be another program of that type or some other type. It was -- the Double-Double was really to focus on a particular phase in our history and I think it served that role very well. As we look into 2018, we do have a couple of things that are quite exciting. We do have the fourth of the Oasis class ships. Even more so, '18 will show Edge class and the Edge class is a new class of ships which I think in its own way will be as innovative and as transformational as Oasis has been. We're very excited about it. We'll probably be talking more about that early next year but Celebrity really has been on a role and I think we'll see that benefits of that if it continues going away. It's going, we'll see the benefits of that in '17 and '18. And then, when Edge comes, I think people are really going to be blown away. So I'm very excited about '18. But the importance of a program like Double-Double is to focus on a particular goal and one of the things that's been very successful for us is everybody's focused on achieving the Double-Double in 2017 and so that's our first one and I will be careful not to dwell too much on what comes after.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is historically when you've headed into wave season and the stronger than the normal book position, do you think that you're borrowing from wave or does that usually lead to stronger incremental pricing because you've just got less inventor
componenttext: First question is historically when you've headed into wave season and the stronger than the normal book position, do you think that you're borrowing from wave or does that usually lead to stronger incremental pricing because you've just got less inventory to sell?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Traditionally, as we've had a stronger book position, obviously the need is less. But if you kind of do it on a capacity adjusted basis, typically that gives us good tailwinds coming into wave as we're in a stronger position as we need less. So I don't th
componenttext: Traditionally, as we've had a stronger book position, obviously the need is less. But if you kind of do it on a capacity adjusted basis, typically that gives us good tailwinds coming into wave as we're in a stronger position as we need less. So I don't think that as an indicator but certainly being in a stronger position allows you to take advantage of the demand as it comes in.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to move quickly to China because it's been one of the key pillars of the bare pieces and the consensus for next year is pricing in China's going to be down 10% to 15%. Can you give us your perspective on what demand is going to look like -
componenttext: And I just want to move quickly to China because it's been one of the key pillars of the bare pieces and the consensus for next year is pricing in China's going to be down 10% to 15%. Can you give us your perspective on what demand is going to look like -- demand growth is going to look like in China next year? And do you think that the supply growth is going to be as big as some would have you believe given that much of the capacities coming in at the back half of last year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, it's Michael. Yes, China is very much a developmental market. It's, we believe, a significant opportunity. We've been in the market for several years now. It represents about 9% of our overall capacity in 2017. Interestingly, in '17, overall capaci
componenttext: Harry, it's Michael. Yes, China is very much a developmental market. It's, we believe, a significant opportunity. We've been in the market for several years now. It represents about 9% of our overall capacity in 2017. Interestingly, in '17, overall capacity in the China market is flat to slightly down because of the sale of Legend which takes it out of the secondary cities. And also for industry capacity in '17, it's actually relatively low growth year in relation to the past years which is probably a good thing. And certainly in Shanghai, which is 60% of the China market approximately, the growth in '17 in Shanghai is less than 10% which is one of the lowest growth rates we've seen for quite some time. Overall, China is accretive to the yields and will continue that way and as Jason commented earlier, current for the position of Q1 China is looking good.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And just a quick follow up, Jason, in China. What efficiency measures can you take even if pricing is flat there to improve your profitability?
componenttext: That's great. And just a quick follow up, Jason, in China. What efficiency measures can you take even if pricing is flat there to improve your profitability?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Harry, I'm just going to jump in and give some comments on this. I mean, we're very much engaged in developing the markets. So at the moment, we're investing in China. We're investing in developing distribution and developing the channels. So at the moment, our focus is developing the market and investing in the market. We believe the opportunity is significant into the future. So we're not actively pursuing efficiencies from that perspective. We're looking at investing and developing.

componenttext: How about what's driving the strength of the North American passengers going to Europe? Is it just easier comparison things, maybe people are less concerned about going to Europe? Is it less capacity? What do you think is driving that improvement?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's tough to pinpoint one thing. I think when there's less events, that certainly helps bring confidence and confidence in people's travel. But I think as we've been saying for sometime, we continue to see strength from the North American c
componenttext: Well, I think it's tough to pinpoint one thing. I think when there's less events, that certainly helps bring confidence and confidence in people's travel. But I think as we've been saying for sometime, we continue to see strength from the North American consumer. Not only do we see that in terms of their current bookings in Q4 and for next year but also, we see it on how they spend each and everyday on our ships. So I don't know if there's a specific thing but obviously Europe is an incredible destination and there's a lot of demand for it. And obviously, there was some events last year that may be caused certain individuals to pause and will think of revisiting that next year.

componenttext: I think that there are several factors. Obviously, Q1 on the yield side will have a positive impact just from the deconsolidation of Pullmantur. But also the strength that we've seen for Harmony and Ovation have been quite strong and Harmony, obviously being in Caribbean and Ovation will in Australia and demand from both of those markets and for those products parks have been exceptional. I wouldn't necessarily say that it is obviously a tough comp because Q1 was strong but there is some good tailwinds going into the first quarter.

componenttext: Your commentary on the Two70 load factors was pretty consistent with what you said coming out into the second quarter. I just want to focus on sort of the last few months in both the Caribbean and Europe. I think in the Caribbean, a lot of investors have been spooked as of late as we look at some of the pricing analysis that's out there. Obviously in the past, it's always difficult to know how many rooms are being booked at a given price. But may be obviously, you've seen some of that in-house or leasing with the advertised prices. Maybe help us connect the dots there? Is it same as normal that it's just not a whole lot of rooms being booked at those rates. What are your thoughts there? And then, on Europe, it sort of sounds like over the past few months, bookings and pricing has maybe strengthened as we get further and further away from the terrorist activity, but maybe just distill the last 3 months [indiscernible]?

componenttext: Well, I think as you're growing from early August to today, people begin to transition and focus on their vacations for '17. But we've actually seen really good booking trends forward-looking for the Caribbean and for Europe. A lot of that at this point in and the year is driven by the North American consumer because they book further out. But as Michael said, we're also seeing positive trends happening for Europe.

componenttext: On the 1.6 million new to cruise, how does that compare to last year and I'm trying to get a sense of the implied growth rate. And also just how that rate might be trending? That's first. Second, I'm just curious what's driving that and what percent of the North American revenue we're talking about here?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Michael. 1.6 million new to cruise, that's for globally. That's all markets obviously it's disproportionate in terms of new emerging markets, so for example, China. In the United States, which of course, is a significant part of our overall busi
componenttext: Dan, it's Michael. 1.6 million new to cruise, that's for globally. That's all markets obviously it's disproportionate in terms of new emerging markets, so for example, China. In the United States, which of course, is a significant part of our overall business, it's approximately 15%. We've had a very productive the year this year with new to cruise and in fact over time, it had been slightly on a decline. This year, we've turned that around and we're seeing a really positive increase in new to cruise and of course, that's very much part of our focus. New to cruise not only in emerging new and developing markets but also in established markets like the U.S.. So we feel quite encouraged by what we're seeing. And part of that is the campaign that we launched at the beginning of the year and also Celebrities campaign, both of those campaigns have components that are very much attracted to new to cruise and when you do the research on how we're positioning and how we're communicating resonates with new to cruise, it's very positive. So we're beginning to see that coming through in our bookings.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Richard and I just add a comment because we often get questions about trends and things that have changed and it's clear the questions are geared to is, is the world changing? Is this a trend in the variables affecting us? But as Michael poin
componenttext: Dan, this is Richard and I just add a comment because we often get questions about trends and things that have changed and it's clear the questions are geared to is, is the world changing? Is this a trend in the variables affecting us? But as Michael pointed out, we actually work to change trends, so there are periods of time where we, for example, as both Royal -- as Michael said, both Royal and Celebrity made a conscious decision this year that there was a stronger opportunity, a good opportunity with first-time cruisers. And so they actually focus more of their marketing, focus more on their message and they actually worked to build that. So when you look at a trend, it's not just is the world changing, but to some extent, it's also what we're doing to shift our customer base. And then, that sometimes messes up some nice trendlines when you're trying to extrapolate from external behavior.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. That's very helpful. And I guess, the second question here. Wondering how big the impact in net yield from the new revenue management technology implemented a while back? And I guess, I'm wondering, with respect to its implementation, just for
componenttext: Very good. That's very helpful. And I guess, the second question here. Wondering how big the impact in net yield from the new revenue management technology implemented a while back? And I guess, I'm wondering, with respect to its implementation, just for some perspective, when airlines put in new revenue management, they tend to go slow and I just got of curious how you characterize where we are with respect to that to Royal?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's one of those things that's impossible to quantify and we put in new yield management system several years ago and everyday that goes by, the yield management systems get stronger because the information from the past and how we read informati
componenttext: I think it's one of those things that's impossible to quantify and we put in new yield management system several years ago and everyday that goes by, the yield management systems get stronger because the information from the past and how we read information over what's happening in local markets and so forth gets better and better. So it's surely a tailwind, to quantify is almost impossible to do but I think really one of the benefits it gives us is the ability to manage demand globally and that allows us to seek the highest yields for every cabin that's available from anywhere in the world. That's obviously great on a revenue management standpoint, it's also great to take advantage of that diversification.

componenttext: A couple of questions. First one is on the retirement and investment capital, does Pullmantur change make any difference to the tons you make? And secondly, just on China, can you talk about how next year the changing proportion of capacity is moving up -- moving from pure charter to more direct distribution?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the ROIC side, on the invested capital side, there really is be no difference because as I said in my remarks, we still own those assets. But maturely as we've been talking about for years, that Pullmantur was a turnaround opportunity and just allows u
componenttext: So the ROIC side, on the invested capital side, there really is be no difference because as I said in my remarks, we still own those assets. But maturely as we've been talking about for years, that Pullmantur was a turnaround opportunity and just allows us to limit some of those turnaround issues as well as get paid for -- the ships and the services. So it's definitely accretive to ROIC but it's on the earnings side, not necessarily on the invested capital side. I'll let Michael take the second question.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stuart, the evolution of distribution, that's something obviously that we've been focused on for quite some time. It's a journey that we're taking. I think what we're seeing is the beginnings of the development of distribution in terms of starting to
componenttext: Yes, Stuart, the evolution of distribution, that's something obviously that we've been focused on for quite some time. It's a journey that we're taking. I think what we're seeing is the beginnings of the development of distribution in terms of starting to mirror and look very much like the North American distribution model in terms of our focus very much is engaged in opening all channels to market and optimizing each channel. That includes our wholesale charter model which we believe has done exceptionally well up to this point and we're going to continue working with our charters but we're also developing direct. We're also developing retail, next cruise, and that's very much we've been engage over sometime there. So I think that's a journey we're taking and over time, we'll see the mix balance out in a very similar way to the markets -- more developed markets.

to the Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. Third Quarter Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Jason Liberty, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for our third quarter earnings call. Joining me here in Miami are Richard Fain, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Adam Goldstein, President and Chief Operating Officer; Michael Bayley, President and
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for our third quarter earnings call. Joining me here in Miami are Richard Fain, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Adam Goldstein, President and Chief Operating Officer; Michael Bayley, President and CEO of Royal Caribbean International; and Carol Cabezas, our Vice President of Investor Relations. 
During this call, we will be referring to a few slides, which have been posted on our investor website, www.rclinvestor.com. 
Before we get started, I would like to refer you to our notice about forward-looking statements, which is on our first slide. During this call, we will be making comments that are forward-looking. These statements do not guarantee future performance and do involve risks and uncertainties. Examples are described in our SEC filings and other disclosures. Additionally, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, which are adjusted as defined, and a reconciliation of these items can be found on our website. 
Richard will begin by providing an overview of the business. I will follow with a recap of our third quarter results, provide an update on the current booking environment and provide our early thoughts on 2017. I will close with guidance for the full year and fourth quarter. We will then open the call up for your questions. 
Richard?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jason and good morning, everybody. It's a pleasure to have the opportunity to share more about our business and our progress to the Double-Double, so let me get right to it. We're quickly coming to the end of 2016, and we'll shortly be starting
componenttext:
Thanks, Jason and good morning, everybody. It's a pleasure to have the opportunity to share more about our business and our progress to the Double-Double, so let me get right to it. 
We're quickly coming to the end of 2016, and we'll shortly be starting the final year of our Double-Double Program. Reaching the Double-Double will be a significant accomplishment for the 65,000 women and men who collectively make Royal Caribbean cruises successful. However, I do want to emphasize that Double-Double is not an end in and of itself. Rather, it represents the completion of another step in our continuous journey of improving shareholder returns. 
The success of the Double-Double rests on 3 pillars: strengthening revenue yields, controlling costs and moderate growth. Our progress on this journey has been steady. Not only has the slope of the curve been very steep, but it's been remarkably strong and predictable. As you can see on Slide 2, both earnings and yields have consistently ended up right around the midpoint of the range that we stated at the beginning of each year. This track record comes despite some unexpected impact from things like foreign exchange and fuel. 
For example, our biggest nondollar market has been the U.K. but sterling has fallen 30% over the last 2 years, and that got a significant push from the recent Brexit end vote. This year is shaping up to deliver in a similar fashion. Our yield guidance today at 4% or better is about the same as it was at the beginning of the year when we adjusted the deconsolidation of Pullmantur. 
Earnings per share expectations on $6 to $6.10 are a little better than our original range despite the number of challenges that came our way this year. So the fact that our year is ending above our original guidance in spite of the challenges is a testament to the focused discipline and will of the team. For that, I express my appreciation. 
I'd also like to take a moment and sit back to discuss some of the developments to our core financial objectives, including achieving investment-grade metrics, improving shareholder returns and moderate capacity growth. I know that many of you model our performance outlook diligently, and you can see that we are now reaching the key financial metrics that are the threshold for investment grade. Getting to this point hasn't been easy but it is important. We are committed to achieving and maintaining a BBB credit status. In this regard, it was particularly satisfying when Moody's issued its upgrade of our improved outlook. It is rewarding to see progress on all our goals, and this is another big one. 
I also know that many of you are up-to-date on our announcements and have noticed our recent increase in dividends. Our dividend level is at an all-time high and is now 4x what it was just over 3 years ago. In the same period, we also executed significant buyback program. As our earnings continue to grow and as conditions warrant, and by that I include earnings and free cash flow, we will continue to engage in the mix of moderate dividend growth and share buyback programs. These steps are clear evidence of our commitment to improving shareholder returns. 
Now turning to the third pillar, moderate capacity growth. That's been a focal point of a lot of conversations. We said before that the pipeline in supply is known, and it's very much constrained by limited shipyard capacity. We said our target is 3% to 5% growth rate, and that's just what we've been doing. Through 2005, our 5 year actual capacity growth rate was just under 4% a year, and for the coming 5 years, it's also just under 4%. 
Now on the demand side, we've seen some markets contract such as the Eastern Mediterranean, but we've also seen new markets expand such as China and Australia. It's important to note that cruising is still under-penetrated in all of our markets including our core markets. We opened up new markets like China because they're growing at extraordinary rates, not because of inadequate demand elsewhere. For example, we're aware that some people have been arguing for years that the U.S. market is saturated. But we've been growing here strongly and consistently in both rate and volume and we expect to continue to do so for years to come. 
Our task is to continue to make people, especially non-cruisers, aware of all the cruising offers. That takes continued effort but it is working. This year alone, we've added more than 1.6 million new to cruise. That demonstrates our continued strength in this market and positions us for what we believe to be a bright future. 
Now before I hand the call back over to Jason, I want to touch on one more point related to environmental stewardship. Protecting the environment is a responsibility we take seriously at Royal Caribbean, both because of the impact on our environment and because it just makes good business sense. We focused heavily on reducing our carbon footprint, and we're proud to publish our energy consumption figures. They consistently show that our burning of fossil fuels shows the lowest figures reported by anyone in our industry. This success comes from a deep focus on finding new and better ways to do things. 
For example, our bubble technology, just more appropriately called our air lubrication system, reduces drag, thereby, reducing the need for burning fuel. But in keeping with our mantra of continuous improvement, we have gone 1 step further. Recently, we partnered with the World Wildlife Fund to take our sustainability performance to the next level. Together with WWF, we have announced publicly goals related to greenhouse gas emissions, sustainable food supply and destination stewardship. This partnership follows exciting progress on a number of other fronts, including our advanced wastewater purification systems and our zero landfill policy already implemented on 17 ships. 
We are also very pleased to be working with the EPA and have their support as we install advanced emissions purification or AEP systems on our ships. This is a massive and expensive task but a very impactful one. These AEP systems scrub more than 98% of the sulfur from our ships' exhaust. 
Lastly, we have recently announced a new class of ships dubbed Icon class. These ships will be powered by LNG and will also utilize the latest fuel cell technology. Fuel cells are the ultimate in smoke-free exhausts. The only emission from fuel cells is pure water. 
In conclusion, it's been a good quarter and the future looks very bright. Brexit and other factors have been unexpected blows but we have more than compensated in other ways. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Jason. Jason?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard. I will begin by taking you through our results for the third quarter. Unless I state otherwise, all metrics are on a constant-currency basis. We have summarized our third quarter results on Slide 3. For the quarter, we generated adju
componenttext:
Thank you, Richard. I will begin by taking you through our results for the third quarter. Unless I state otherwise, all metrics are on a constant-currency basis. 
We have summarized our third quarter results on Slide 3. For the quarter, we generated adjusted net income of $3.20 per share, $0.10 better than the previous guidance. About half of the outperformance was driven by better revenue with the other half of the beat driven by a weaker dollar and lower fuel prices. Third quarter net revenue yield was better than expected, up 2.9% year-over-year. Strength in close-in demand for North American products was the primary driver of the outperformance. 
Onboard revenue yields for the quarter did not disappoint, with yields up 4.8% for the quarter. The growth was mainly driven by beverage packages and increasing demand for VOOM and Accelerate, our high-speed Internet offerings for World Caribbean International and Celebrity Cruises, respectively. Costs were as expected for the quarter with net cruise costs excluding fuel, down 1.6%. 
Before I get into discussing booking trends, I would like to discuss deviations between the quarters. Our yield came in slightly better than expected in the third quarter and are expected to be slightly lower than our previous expectations in the fourth quarter. As a result, our yields for the full year are essentially unchanged. We often get asked whether these small aberrations between quarters signify a trend. The answer is no, and I would like to explain why. The reality is that we manage a large and diversified portfolio of brands, markets and products. This complex portfolio obviously has minor deviations especially in a period as short as a quarter. This year is a good example. Something as simple and insignificant as the delay in the deployment of the Empress of the Seas will drive yields to be lower for the fourth quarter than we originally expected. This delay has no long-term significance but it does affect quarterly figures. 
As Richard mentioned, our track record is pretty good, and Slide 2 shows that over the past several years, we have been able to deliver annual yield and earning results in line with the original guidance we set for the year. We don't see this immaterial aberration between Q3 and Q4 to be a trend, just a reflection of managing a global and diversified portfolio. This is further supported by the 2017 booking trend commentary I will be providing shortly. 
Now I will share trends in the demand environment for the balance of 2016 and provide early insights into 2017. Let me start off by discussing the fourth quarter where our mix of deployment shifts versus the summer. We have more capacity in the Caribbean and Australia and less in the Mediterranean. Our year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter Caribbean deployment is driven by the additions of both Harmony of the Sea and Empress of the Sea in South Florida. As a result, Caribbean itineraries will account for half of our Q4 capacity. We expect Caribbean yields to be up mid-single digits for the quarter, which as I previously mentioned, is softer than our previous expectations due to the delay in opening Empress of the Seas for sale. Expectations for the rest of the Caribbean products remain relatively unchanged. Asia Pacific and Europe itineraries are generally performing in line with our previous outlook. So in summary, we are 94% booked for the fourth quarter, and with the exception of Empress, yields are shaping up as expected. 
Moving on to 2017. I want to start by providing you an overview of some of the structural factors and deployment changes that play a part in the upcoming year. I will then discuss the early trends we are seeing in the business. We will see a benefit in the first half of the year from the addition of both Harmony of the Seas and Ovation of the Seas. We will have a tailwind to our yields related to the deconsolidation of Pullmantur, which is worth a little over 250 basis points for the first half of next year. As a reminder, our portion of Pullmantur's results will be reported as an equity pickup, and since we continue to own the vessels, we will continue to incur depreciation for the ships. Lastly, our joint venture with TUI Cruises will receive another new ship during the second quarter. 
As we announced earlier this year, Legend of the Seas will exit the fleet at the end of the first quarter. This sale is very much in line with our fleet strategy of opportunistically selling order capacity. We are making several changes to our itinerary mix in 2017 that will reduce exposure to the Eastern Mediterranean while bringing new hardware to the Caribbean and moderately growing the Asia Pacific region. 
Our Caribbean deployment will increase in 2017 and will represent just under half of our total capacity. This increase is largely due to the expanded season for both Harmony of the Seas and Celebrity Equinox. Both of these ships will remain in the Caribbean year-round versus sailing in Europe as they did during the summer of 2016. The change in deployment for these ships combined with the deconsolidation of Pullmantur are driving a reduction in Mediterranean capacity. As a result, Europe will represent 15% of our overall capacity in 2017 versus 20% in 2016. 
Asia Pacific itineraries will account for approximately 20% of our capacity, which is relatively consistent with 2016. Our capacity in China will decrease slightly as the longer season of Ovation of the Seas is only offsetting a portion of the reduction due to the sale of the Legend of the Seas. 
While it's still too early to provide guidance for next year, I will share some preliminary insights. Our booked position is stronger than last year as we are up in both pricing and load factors across all major markets for light deployment. This is particularly noteworthy when you consider that our book load factor has improved each year for the past several years, culminating in a record high for next year. Our Caribbean and Alaska products are trending well despite very difficult comparisons in 2016, and bookings for European sales are up nicely year-over-year, driven by strong demand from North America. We are also pleased with how the winter Asia Pacific season is shaping up, with both Australia and China sailings booked ahead of prior year load factors in the first quarter. Although it's still early in the booking window, these insights provide added confidence in our path towards the Double-Double, and we expect that 2017 will be our 8th conservative year of yield improvement. 
If you turn to Slide 4, you will see our guidance for the full year 2016. Net revenue yields are expected to be up 4% or better, essentially unchanged from last quarter's guidance. Our cost guidance is also unchanged with net cruise costs, excluding fuel, expected to be up approximately 1%. Our fuel costs for the year have decreased since our last call to $720 million driven by rate, and we are 68% hedged for the remainder of 2016 at a price of $535 per metric ton. Based on current fuel prices, interest rates and currency exchange rates, our adjusted earnings per share guidance is expected to be in the range of $6 to $6.10 per share, unchanged from previous guidance. 
To summarize, the changes we have made since the last call, we exceeded the third quarter by $0.10 per share, approximately half of which was driven by the outperformance of our North American products. This beat is helping to offset the previously mentioned impact from the delay in the deployment of Empress of the Seas. A weaker U.S. dollar and lower fuel prices contributed the other half of the third quarter beat. However, this trend reverses itself in the fourth quarter. 
Now I would like to walk you through our fourth quarter guidance on Slide 5. Net yields are expected to be up approximately 6%. The year-over-year increase is being driven by the deconsolidation of Pullmantur and strong trend on our Caribbean and Australia itineraries. Harmony of the Seas in the Caribbean and Ovation of the Seas in Australia are doing particularly well. Net cruise costs excluding fuel are expected to be down approximately 1.5%, and we have included $189 million of fuel expense for the quarter. Taking all of this into account, we expect adjusted earnings per share to be approximately $1.20 for the quarter, which represents nearly 30% growth year-over-year. 
With that, I will ask our operator to open up the call for a question-and-answer session.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, obviously there's been a lot of concern about just the promotional environment, particularly in the Caribbean. Can you expand on that and just what you're seeing right now and if you feel the need to be more -- a little bit more pro
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, obviously there's been a lot of concern about just the promotional environment, particularly in the Caribbean. Can you expand on that and just what you're seeing right now and if you feel the need to be more -- a little bit more promotional right now just because of some of the incremental capacity or just how you're thinking about that?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's -- sorry, Jared, it's Michael. yes, We're feeling pretty good about the Caribbean. Some things looking good, especially on volume and rate with the capacity increase and '16 shaping up pretty well. It looks very typical in terms of what we're
componenttext: David, it's -- sorry, Jared, it's Michael. yes, We're feeling pretty good about the Caribbean. Some things looking good, especially on volume and rate with the capacity increase and '16 shaping up pretty well. It looks very typical in terms of what we're seeing with booking patterns in Q4 as we've seen in previous years. So everything's looking quite normal. Obviously, promotional activity ebbs and flows. We had Hurricane Matthew blowing through the week before last, so we had about a week of drop in bookings which is inevitable as it moves its way up the East Coast. And then I think we did and others certainly tried to stimulate the demand by putting in some promotional activity, which then the response was very good. We had a promotion last week, which was the second-best performing promotion in the brand's history.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Beckel with Bernstein Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could -- maybe a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up to
componenttext: I was wondering if you could -- maybe a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up to that, what are some of the more significant levers on cost you can pull if yields do come in lighter than expected?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about some of the chunki
componenttext: We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about some of the chunkier things that we've been doing on the cost side. And really, over the past year or so, a lot of this is dozens [ph] of little things that we do to become more efficient across our business. There are always small levers to pull, to try to write yourself if there is yield challenges, but there is nothing specific that I would call out. But I think -- I would leave this point by saying that I think we've shown, over the past several years, management's commitment to cost control and try to become more efficient year-over-year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So
componenttext: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So the yield -- the risk of continued yield pressures in China, supply growth in the Caribbean and then also FX fuel headwinds for next year. So regarding Asia Pacific, I think you said that in China -- you said that your book position is -- China's ahead of -- you're ahead of in-load, so I was just wondering if for a moment you could touch upon maybe how you -- if you think where yields could come out next year? If you think you could see yield pressure again in China, and then also your confidence level of growing yields in the Caribbean? And then, if there's any way -- I mean, I think a lot of people are doing the math based on where FX and fuel is today to kind of calculate where that might impact next year, so if you could touch upon that as well.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this poin
componenttext: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this point in the year, we have pretty good visibility into the first quarter, it's been encouraging and hopefully those trends continue on as that product books further out here over time. And then when we talk about the Caribbean, and I would also include Europe in there, at this point in time in the year, a lot of that is driven by the North American consumer. And as I commented in my remarks that we have seen very positive trends in both the rate and volume basis for the Caribbean as well as for our European products. And then to answer your question on the currency side, certainly, the strength of the dollar relative to the pound has been challenging. If you want to say, well, what it has kind of been since the last call, it's probably hurt us by about $0.12 to $0.15. And so there's -- there are always headwinds in our business that we have to focus on and overcome, but that's kind of been the impact since the last time we spoke here in early August.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up on kind of some puts and takes for next year, because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points from yields in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management f
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up on kind of some puts and takes for next year, because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points from yields in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management fee as well. So maybe if you could help us understand how the full picture -- the full mathematical picture works for Pullmantur.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit, and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit, and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates to the management fee. So it's a small contributor but not something I would specifically call out in buildup of the yield.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to ask about the Empress because, I guess, our impression has been that you are maybe not opening up Empress for new sailings because you were hoping for a new Caribbean itinerary to open up before the end of the year. So I just wanted to ask what your expectation. Is it still potentially that could open up before the end of the year? Or is it -- is the idea to keep Empress sort of into Q1 without opening it up for new sailings yet?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we were -- as we were continuing the deployment for Empress, because as you know, Robin, we deploy a ship or opening up -- or open up a deployment for a ship about 12 to 18 months ahead of time. I think we have seen or we have obviously been
componenttext: So obviously, we were -- as we were continuing the deployment for Empress, because as you know, Robin, we deploy a ship or opening up -- or open up a deployment for a ship about 12 to 18 months ahead of time. I think we have seen or we have obviously been in conversations about what the future deployment of that ship could be and that did not resolve itself in the back half of this year, and that's really what caused the impact on Empress because we effectively open up for deployment in August. I think we continue to look for that ship to potentially have some other deployment, but I don't think we will be holding back our sailings in the future. And we'll deal with it as maybe some of that new deployment comes available.
