componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could -- it may be a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up
componenttext: I was wondering if you could -- it may be a little early, but I was wondering if you could talk about net cruise cost growth for next year, just reminding us what some of the key puts and takes are when considering modeling cost growth. And as a follow-up to that, what are some of the more significant levers on cost you can pull if yields do come in lighter than expected?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about som
componenttext: Thanks, David. We're still going to our planning process for next year but as we've said in the past, we need to continue to control our costs like we have over the past several years. I know early on in our Double-Double Program, we talked more about some of the chunkier things that we've been doing on the cost side. And really, over the past year or so, a lot of this is down to the little things that we do to become more efficient across our business. There are always small levers to pull, to try to right yourself if there is yield challenges, but there is nothing specific that I would call out. But I think -- I would leave this point with saying that I think we've shown, over the past several years, management's commitment to cost control and try to become more efficient year-over-year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So
componenttext: Jason, thanks for the color that you gave for next year. I just wanted to see if we could get a little bit more granular just to clarify things, because obviously, there's 3 -- from our perspective, there's 3 overarching concerns for next year, right? So the yield -- the risk of continued yield pressures in China, supply growth in the Caribbean and then also FX fuel headwinds for next year. So regarding Asia Pacific, I think you said that in China -- you said that your booked position is -- China's ahead of -- you're ahead of in-load, so I was just wondering if for a moment you could touch upon maybe how you -- if you think where yields could come out next year? If you think you could see yield pressure again in China, and then also your confidence level of growing yields in the Caribbean? And then, if there's any way -- I mean, I think a lot of people are doing the math based on where FX and fuel is today to kind of calculate where that might impact next year, so if you could touch upon that as well.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this poin
componenttext: Sure. Well, first off, when we kind of think about next year, it's obviously too early to provide any guidance and any guidance by product. But what we do have is we have where we're currently booked. The commentary on Asia Pac, which really, at this point in the year, we have pretty good visibility into the first quarter, it's been encouraging and hopefully those trends continue on as that product books further out here over time. And then when we talk about the Caribbean, and I would also include Europe in there, at this point in time in the year, a lot of that is driven by the North American consumer. And as I commented in my remarks that we have seen very positive trends in both the rate and volume basis for the Caribbean as well as for our European products. And then to answer your question on the currency side, certainly, the strength of the dollar relative to the pound has been challenging. If you want to say, well, what it has kind of been since the last call, it's probably hurt us by about $0.12 to $0.15. And so there's -- there are always headwinds in our business that we have to focus on and overcome, but that's kind of been the impact since the last time we spoke here in early August.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up on kind of some puts and takes for next year, because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points from yields in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management f
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up on kind of some puts and takes for next year, because you mentioned that there will be a tailwind from Pullmantur, 250 basis points from yields in the first half. There's also -- you also get a benefit from the management fee as well. So maybe if you could help us understand how the full picture -- the full mathematical picture works for Pullmantur.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit, and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there is obviously through the deconsolidation, there is the benefit, and that's effectively kind of included in that estimate of the 250 basis points in the first half of the year. The balance of that for the year is immaterial as it relates to the management fee. So it's a small contributor, but not something I would specifically call out in the buildup of yield.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the Empress because, I guess, our impression has been that you are maybe not opening up Empress for new sailings because you were hoping for a new Caribbean itinerary to open up before the end of the year. So I just wanted to ask wha
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the Empress because, I guess, our impression has been that you are maybe not opening up Empress for new sailings because you were hoping for a new Caribbean itinerary to open up before the end of the year. So I just wanted to ask what your expectation -- is it still potentially that could open up before the end of the year? Or is it -- is the idea to keep Empress sort of into Q1 without opening it up for new sailings yet?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we were -- as we were continuing [ph] the deployment for Empress, because as you know, Robin, we deploy a ship or opening up -- or open up a deployment for a ship about 12 to 18 months ahead of time. I think we had seen or we have obviously
componenttext: So obviously, we were -- as we were continuing [ph] the deployment for Empress, because as you know, Robin, we deploy a ship or opening up -- or open up a deployment for a ship about 12 to 18 months ahead of time. I think we had seen or we have obviously been in conversations about what the future deployment of that ship could be and that did not resolve itself in the back half of this year, and that's really what caused the impact on Empress because we effectively opened up for deployment in August. I think we continue to look for that ship to potentially have some other deployment, but I don't think we will be holding back our sailings in the future. And we'll deal with it as maybe some of that new deployment comes available.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just on, for my follow-up question. There's...
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just on, for my follow-up question. There's...

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a comment, Robin, and it's already open for next year, Empress.
componenttext: Just a comment, Robin, and it's already open for next year, Empress.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For just reg -- for existing Caribbean itineraries?
componenttext: For just reg -- for existing Caribbean itineraries?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in Q1, yes.
componenttext: Yes, in Q1, yes.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's great. And then for my follow-up question. There's been some reports in the Korean media that China is limiting some tour package travel to Korea for political reasons and just wondering if you're seeing any kind of impact at all since cruis
componenttext: Right. That's great. And then for my follow-up question. There's been some reports in the Korean media that China is limiting some tour package travel to Korea for political reasons and just wondering if you're seeing any kind of impact at all since cruises from China call on Korean ports. Any impact at all of getting the sense that there's going to be some kind of a limit or any time [ph] that you've seen so far for mainland Chinese visitors going to Korea by cruise?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, it's Michael. No, we've seen no impact whatsoever. We think it's very much related to the -- a type of package that's offered that really is all about encouraging Chinese customers to go to Korea specifically for shopping trips, and we think it's r
componenttext: Robin, it's Michael. No, we've seen no impact whatsoever. We think it's very much related to the -- a type of package that's offered that really is all about encouraging Chinese customers to go to Korea specifically for shopping trips, and we think it's related to that. So there's the packages put into the market that are incredibly low cost, and of course, they bring their customers over and make their revenue from the retail. So we feel as if that's something that's very specifically focused. So we don't -- we have not seen anything, and we don't believe there will be any impact to us.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple things. I wanted to revisit the mix shift with the Harmony and the Equinox, Jason, that you called out. Is that going to be yield accretive given Europe traditionally has higher yields than the Caribbean? Just on -- just that shift for the s
componenttext: Just a couple things. I wanted to revisit the mix shift with the Harmony and the Equinox, Jason, that you called out. Is that going to be yield accretive given Europe traditionally has higher yields than the Caribbean? Just on -- just that shift for the similar comparisons year-over-year, just a little color on that, please. And then fuel, you guys had been fairly aggressive towards the high end or above the higher end of your 40% to 60% range in hedging, especially you put -- appeared to have put on quite a bit when oil was in the 30s. Maybe a little bit more color on where your weighted average hedges are looking into '17 and '18. And then if you continue to view as layering on more aggressively or maybe just sort of backed off a little bit on that as you layer out 12, 24, 36 months.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So, Tim, on the first question as it relates to Harmony and Equinox. First, trends or demand for Harmony has been exceptional, and we do expect that Harmony, being here next year, for it to be yield accretive and certainly helps us a lot in the fir
componenttext: Great. So, Tim, on the first question as it relates to Harmony and Equinox. First, trends or demand for Harmony has been exceptional, and we do expect that Harmony, being here next year, for it to be yield accretive and certainly helps us a lot in the first half of the year. Equinox mainly was in the Eastern Mediterranean and really kind of in the center of a lot of movements we had to make with her with some of the geopolitical events that were happening. And so we do expect the Equinox to be yield accretive to the corporation next year. On the fuel side, in '17, we're hedged about 60%. The average hedge rate there is about $508 and in '18, we're 45% hedged and we're about $452, is the average hedge. And we continue to focus in -- on having a hedge program to minimize the volatility within our P&L, and we also respect that there's typically an inverse relationship between fuel and currency. We also take into consideration the fuel curve, and it has flattened out. And so there's -- earlier last year, we did take advantage and put a little bit more hedging on -- in '16 and in the outer years, but you should I think expect us to continue to be pretty consistent to the past of that kind of 40% to 60% side of things and again, with a goal of minimizing volatility within the P&L.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And what my follow-up would be related to Europe. You said you've seen very good bookings so far out of North America, given specifically how it books early for Europe. Any color by region? I mean, is it tilted more towards Northern Europe or
componenttext: Okay, great. And what my follow-up would be related to Europe. You said you've seen very good bookings so far out of North America, given specifically how it books early for Europe. Any color by region? I mean, is it tilted more towards Northern Europe or the Western Med, where everything is sort of consolidated to in the Med, just any additional color or how the Brits also are booking?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, it's Michael. Yes, Europe's looking quite good for '17 when we look at our forward bookings. Obviously, Eastern Med capacity is down versus last year and the year before. We've been aware of that. So it's pretty much all over Europe. So Northern Euro
componenttext: Tim, it's Michael. Yes, Europe's looking quite good for '17 when we look at our forward bookings. Obviously, Eastern Med capacity is down versus last year and the year before. We've been aware of that. So it's pretty much all over Europe. So Northern Europe, obviously, is doing quite well and also Western Med. European markets, typically a later booking than the American market. It's the American market that seems to be doing quite well at the moment for Europe. And the British market, surprisingly is quite robust. We were thinking that we would see more of an impact, a little bit of an impact in on-board spend, but nothing really material.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski with Stifel.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to ask the Double-Double question a little bit differently. And one of the questions we get a lot from investors is how are you guys going to achieve the Double-Double next year without buying back a significant amount of your stock or getting s
componenttext: So I want to ask the Double-Double question a little bit differently. And one of the questions we get a lot from investors is how are you guys going to achieve the Double-Double next year without buying back a significant amount of your stock or getting some massive benefit from Pullmantur? Can you maybe help us think about the bridge to get around or get close to the Double-Double range? Meaning, if you do a midpoint this year of 6, call it, 6.05, from a very high level, how do you get up close to that 6.78 or 6.80 number? That would be pretty helpful.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Steve. Obviously, we won't kind of talk about any guidance for next year, but really, you need us to continue to show strong cost control and have modest yield improvement, and that gets you most of the way. And then obviously, there is som
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Steve. Obviously, we won't kind of talk about any guidance for next year, but really, you need us to continue to show strong cost control and have modest yield improvement, and that gets you most of the way. And then obviously, there is some benefit we get from the deconsolidation of Pullmantur, but that's really a small amount of that pie.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's Richard here, and one of the things that we've tried to emphasize for the last 3 or 4 years is we put in place the Double-Double Program with an idea that we want to motivate our team and focus our team on a particular target, but it wasn't so
componenttext: Steve, it's Richard here, and one of the things that we've tried to emphasize for the last 3 or 4 years is we put in place the Double-Double Program with an idea that we want to motivate our team and focus our team on a particular target, but it wasn't something, and we've said this before, that require heroic efforts. So we do need good cost control. We think we have been showing that. We do need moderate yield improvements. We think we've been showing that. And I think as you look to the Double-Double year, obviously it's a complicated set of all of the things that happened in our business. But as we simply look at where we are today and with the moderate kind of yield improvements that we're looking for, we don't think we need to do anything heroic to make the Double-Double. And we continue to believe we'll do it.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one more comment, Steve. I think, just always appreciating the sensitivities because every 1% percent change in yield is about $70 million. And so by just keeping your costs managed, most of that drops to the bottom line. And that in itself drive
componenttext: And just one more comment, Steve. I think, just always appreciating the sensitivities because every 1% percent change in yield is about $70 million. And so by just keeping your costs managed, most of that drops to the bottom line. And that in itself drives that difference in earnings.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then second question, and you guys might kill me for asking this, but I know we're not even remotely close to 2017 or done with 2017. But have you guys given any thought to what's beyond 2017 and what's beyond the Double-Double? Is -- loo
componenttext: Okay, great. And then second question, and you guys might kill me for asking this, but I know we're not even remotely close to 2017 or done with 2017. But have you guys given any thought to what's beyond 2017 and what's beyond the Double-Double? Is -- looking back, is this something that you guys are -- obviously, you have fully embraced it, but is there something that potentially could come once this is over? Meaning, another type of program like the Double-Double?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the beauty of having -- Steve, I think it -- we're not going to kill you for it. It's a reasonable question, and it's in fact, something that we ask ourselves all the time. And I did actually, I think, I included in my comments something that the Doubl
componenttext: So the beauty of having -- Steve, I think it -- we're not going to kill you for it. It's a reasonable question, and it's in fact, something that we ask ourselves all the time. And I did actually, I think, I included in my comments something that the Double-Double is a step on the journey. We -- in terms of what comes after Double-Double, I don't know whether it'll be another program of that type or some other type. It was -- the Double-Double was really to focus on a particular phase in our history, and I think it served that role very well. As we look to 2018, we do have a couple of things that are quite exciting. We do have the fourth of the Oasis class ships. But I'd say, even more so, '18 will show Edge class. And the Edge class is a new class of ships which I think, in its own way, will be as innovative and as transformational as Oasis has been. We're very excited about it. We'll probably be talking more about that early next year. But Celebrity really has been on a roll, and I think we'll see the benefits of that. If it continues going the way it's going, we'll see the benefits of that in '17 and '18. And then when Edge comes, I think people are really going to be blown away. So I'm very excited about '18. But the importance of a program like Double-Double is to focus on a particular goal. And one of the things that's been very successful for us is everybody is focused on achieving the Double-Double in 2017. And so that's our first one, and I will be careful not to dwell too much on what comes after.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis with Nomura.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is, historically, when you've headed into wave season and a stronger-than-the-normal booked position, do you think that you're borrowing from wave or does that usually lead to stronger incremental pricing because you've just got less invent
componenttext: First question is, historically, when you've headed into wave season and a stronger-than-the-normal booked position, do you think that you're borrowing from wave or does that usually lead to stronger incremental pricing because you've just got less inventory to sell?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, traditionally, as we've had a stronger book position, obviously the need is less. But if you were to kind of do it on a capacity adjusted basis, I would say that typically that gives us good tailwinds coming into wave as we're in a stronger positio
componenttext: Harry, traditionally, as we've had a stronger book position, obviously the need is less. But if you were to kind of do it on a capacity adjusted basis, I would say that typically that gives us good tailwinds coming into wave as we're in a stronger position as we need less. So I don't think that's necessarily an indicator, but certainly being in a stronger position allows you to take advantage of the demand as it comes in.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to move quickly to China because it's been one of the key pillars of the bear thesis, and the consensus for next year is that pricing in China is going to be down 10% to 15%. Can you give us your perspective on what demand is going to look
componenttext: And I just want to move quickly to China because it's been one of the key pillars of the bear thesis, and the consensus for next year is that pricing in China is going to be down 10% to 15%. Can you give us your perspective on what demand is going to look like -- demand growth is going to look like in China next year? And do you think that the supply growth is going to be as big as some would have you believe given that much of the capacity is coming in, in the back half of next year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, it's Michael. Yes, China is very much a developmental market. It's, we believe, a significant opportunity. We've been in the market for several years now. It represents about 9% of our overall capacity in 2017. Interestingly, in '17, for oil, our o
componenttext: Harry, it's Michael. Yes, China is very much a developmental market. It's, we believe, a significant opportunity. We've been in the market for several years now. It represents about 9% of our overall capacity in 2017. Interestingly, in '17, for oil, our overall capacity in the China market is flat to slightly down because of the sale of Legend, which takes it out of the secondary cities. And also for industry capacity in '17, it's actually a relatively low growth year in relation to the past years, which is probably a good thing. And certainly, in Shanghai, which is 60% of the China market approximately, the growth in '17 in Shanghai is less than 10%, which is one of the lowest growth rates we've seen for quite some time. Overall, China is accretive to the yields and will continue that way. And as Jason commented earlier, our current forward book position of Q1 China is looking good.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And just a quick follow up, Jason, in China. What efficiency measures can you take even if pricing is flat there to improve your profitability?
componenttext: That's great. And just a quick follow up, Jason, in China. What efficiency measures can you take even if pricing is flat there to improve your profitability?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, I'm just going to jump in and give some comments on this. I mean, we're very much engaged in developing the markets. So at the moment, we're investing in China. We're investing in developing distribution and developing the channels. So at the momen
componenttext: Harry, I'm just going to jump in and give some comments on this. I mean, we're very much engaged in developing the markets. So at the moment, we're investing in China. We're investing in developing distribution and developing the channels. So at the moment, our focus is developing the market and investing in the market. We believe the opportunity is significant into the future. So we're not actively pursuing efficiencies from that perspective. We're looking at investing and developing.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian with Citigroup.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the comment that Q1 China is looking good, which is encouraging. How are your negotiations right now with the larger charter companies going for 2017? Any color and when you think those will be completed?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the comment that Q1 China is looking good, which is encouraging. How are your negotiations right now with the larger charter companies going for 2017? Any color and when you think those will be completed?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The negotiations are in process. We're feeling quite good about where we are in terms of the major charterers and the wholesalers in the market. Obviously, we have a long-term relationship with the key charterers, and we're encouraged by what we're seeing
componenttext: The negotiations are in process. We're feeling quite good about where we are in terms of the major charterers and the wholesalers in the market. Obviously, we have a long-term relationship with the key charterers, and we're encouraged by what we're seeing for '17 in terms of the dialogue and negotiations that we have with them, and we feel quite optimistic about that.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. I won't ask you to quantify optimistic but...
componenttext: Good. I won't ask you to quantify optimistic but...

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You can ask, Greg. We just won't answer.
componenttext: You can ask, Greg. We just won't answer.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason won't let me.
componenttext: Jason won't let me.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How about what's driving the strength in the North American passengers going to Europe? Is it just easier comparison things, maybe people are less concerned about going to Europe? Is it less capacity? What do you think is driving that improvement?
componenttext: How about what's driving the strength in the North American passengers going to Europe? Is it just easier comparison things, maybe people are less concerned about going to Europe? Is it less capacity? What do you think is driving that improvement?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's tough to pinpoint one thing. Obviously, I think when there's less events, that certainly helps bring confidence and confidence in people's travel. But I mean, I think as we've been saying for some time, we continue to see strength from
componenttext: Well, I think it's tough to pinpoint one thing. Obviously, I think when there's less events, that certainly helps bring confidence and confidence in people's travel. But I mean, I think as we've been saying for some time, we continue to see strength from the North American consumer. And not only do we see that in terms of their current bookings in Q4 and for next year, but also we see it in how they spend each and every day on our ships. So I don't know if there's a specific thing, but obviously Europe is an incredible destination and there's a lot of demand for it. And, obviously, there were some events last year that maybe caused certain individuals to pause and it looks like they're revisiting that for next year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just have a couple of questions on the pound specifically. So the more recent devaluation, I'm curious if you're doing anything to kind of help bolster onboard spending. I know you said earlier it's remained pretty resilient, but I didn't know if that kin
componenttext: Just have a couple of questions on the pound specifically. So the more recent devaluation, I'm curious if you're doing anything to kind of help bolster onboard spending. I know you said earlier it's remained pretty resilient, but I didn't know if that kind of took into account the more recent step down. And then separately, Jason, can you remind us how much you have left on your share repurchase plan at this point?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sharon, I'll just talk a little bit about the pound and how we're approaching that but -- from the perspective on both spend. We've ratcheted up our pre-cruise marketing with bundling packages more aggressively than we've done in the past, and we see a be
componenttext: Sharon, I'll just talk a little bit about the pound and how we're approaching that but -- from the perspective on both spend. We've ratcheted up our pre-cruise marketing with bundling packages more aggressively than we've done in the past, and we see a better response pickup rate from the British consumer in terms of the packaging that we put into the market. So I think we see it a little bit but it's, I think, less than we originally thought we would see in terms of devaluation.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Sharon, on your question on share repurchase, we did complete the $500 million share repurchase in the third quarter.
componenttext: And then, Sharon, on your question on share repurchase, we did complete the $500 million share repurchase in the third quarter.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you -- is there any timing when the board would discuss another share repurchase program?
componenttext: Do you -- is there any timing when the board would discuss another share repurchase program?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The board is always evaluating things such as share repurchase or capital returns to shareholders. And, obviously, recently the 28% increase in the dividend was one of those actions they thought was a good idea to do.
componenttext: The board is always evaluating things such as share repurchase or capital returns to shareholders. And, obviously, recently the 28% increase in the dividend was one of those actions they thought was a good idea to do.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would also pay attention to our free cash flow figures since obviously, that is a key factor in the board's thought process.
componenttext: And I would also pay attention to our free cash flow figures since obviously, that is a key factor in the board's thought process.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And your next question comes from Assia Georgieva with Infinity Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: This is Assia. I had a couple of related questions. First of all, Jason, you mentioned Empress was about $0.06 to $0.07 to Q4. Is it -- is that about a 1% deal detriment in the quarter?

componenttextpreview: That's right, Assia. It's slightly over 100 basis points for the quarter. So without that, we would be at about 7%. And then also, there's some rounding as well in terms of probably what the implied yield was for the fourth quarter.
componenttext: That's right, Assia. It's slightly over 100 basis points for the quarter. So without that, we would be at about 7%. And then also, there's some rounding as well in terms of probably what the implied yield was for the fourth quarter.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And given that even for Q1 '17, the ship was opened up relatively late compared to what you have traditionally done. Should we expect a similar detriment for Q1?
componenttext: Okay. And given that even for Q1 '17, the ship was opened up relatively late compared to what you have traditionally done. Should we expect a similar detriment for Q1?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Assia, it's Michael. No, I think we opened up earlier. We've got marketing behind it, so I think we're -- we really were holding it late in '16 and hoping for some -- for the itinerary change. But we're better -- in a better position for '17.
componenttext: Assia, it's Michael. No, I think we opened up earlier. We've got marketing behind it, so I think we're -- we really were holding it late in '16 and hoping for some -- for the itinerary change. But we're better -- in a better position for '17.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense, Michael. And lastly, without having to quantify anything on Q1 because I know you'd rather not do that, we are facing pretty tough comps, and I think the industry in general had done very well. Do you expect that, on a sequential b
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense, Michael. And lastly, without having to quantify anything on Q1 because I know you'd rather not do that, we are facing pretty tough comps, and I think the industry in general had done very well. Do you expect that, on a sequential basis, Q1 might be a little bit more of a challenge than Q4, just very qualitatively?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there are several factors. Obviously, Q1 on the yield side will have a positive impact from just the deconsolidation of Pullmantur. But also the strength that we've seen for Harmony and Ovation have been quite strong, and Harmony will, obviou
componenttext: I think that there are several factors. Obviously, Q1 on the yield side will have a positive impact from just the deconsolidation of Pullmantur. But also the strength that we've seen for Harmony and Ovation have been quite strong, and Harmony will, obviously, be in Caribbean and Ovation will be in Australia. And demand from both of those markets and for those products have been exceptional. So I wouldn't necessarily say that -- it is obviously a tough comp because Q1 was strong, but there are some good tailwinds going into the first quarter.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Hardiman with Wedbush Securities.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your commentary on the 2017 loads factors was pretty consistent with what you said coming out of the second quarter. I just wanted to focus on sort of the last few months in both the Caribbean and Europe. I think in the Caribbean, a lot of investors have
componenttext: Your commentary on the 2017 loads factors was pretty consistent with what you said coming out of the second quarter. I just wanted to focus on sort of the last few months in both the Caribbean and Europe. I think in the Caribbean, a lot of investors have been spooked as of late as we look at some of the pricing analysis that's out there. Obviously, in the past, it's always difficult to know how many rooms are being booked at a given price. But maybe, obviously, you've seen some of that analysis or at least some of those advertised prices. Maybe help us connect the dots there. Is it the same as normal that it's just not a whole lot of rooms being booked at those rates? What are your thoughts there? And then on Europe, it sort of sounds like over the past few months, bookings and pricing has maybe strengthened as we get further and further away from the terrorist activity, but maybe just distill the last 3 months here.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as you're going from early August to today, people begin to transition and focus on winter [ph] vacations for '17. I think some of -- as Michael commented, there were some tactical activity that you probably saw in the market and that was dr
componenttext: Well, I think as you're going from early August to today, people begin to transition and focus on winter [ph] vacations for '17. I think some of -- as Michael commented, there were some tactical activity that you probably saw in the market and that was driven around Hurricane Matthew and that would probably the best example of where you would have seen that. But we've actually seen really good booking trends forward-looking for the Caribbean and for Europe. A lot of that at this point in the year is driven by the North American consumer because they book further out. And -- but as Michael said, we're also seeing positive trends happening for Europe.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then I guess just once and for all with respect to this Double-Double, obviously the EPS target is technically $6.78, but I think you've mentioned, maybe offline, that you're going to need to get to $7 for the ROIC target to still
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then I guess just once and for all with respect to this Double-Double, obviously the EPS target is technically $6.78, but I think you've mentioned, maybe offline, that you're going to need to get to $7 for the ROIC target to still be in play. Which number -- obviously, as you get closer to 2017, that $0.22 difference becomes pretty material. How should we think about the earnings power for next year implied in the Double-Double?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, at this point, we're not going to get into providing guidance for next year. And I think for us, we're focus on hitting both targets, the earnings target as well as the ROIC target. And we'll address specifically what we think that earnings r
componenttext: Yes. I mean, at this point, we're not going to get into providing guidance for next year. And I think for us, we're focus on hitting both targets, the earnings target as well as the ROIC target. And we'll address specifically what we think that earnings range will be in late January or early February when we provide guidance for next year. But good try.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the 1.6 million new to cruise, how does that compare to last year? And I'm trying to get a sense of the implied growth rate here, and also just how that rate might be trending. That's first. Second, I'm just curious what's driving that and what percent
componenttext: On the 1.6 million new to cruise, how does that compare to last year? And I'm trying to get a sense of the implied growth rate here, and also just how that rate might be trending. That's first. Second, I'm just curious what's driving that and what percent of the North American revenue we're talking about here.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Michael. 1.6 million new to cruise, that's for globally. That's all markets. Obviously, it's disproportionate in terms of new emerging markets, so for example, China. In the United States, which of course, is a significant percentage of our over
componenttext: Dan, it's Michael. 1.6 million new to cruise, that's for globally. That's all markets. Obviously, it's disproportionate in terms of new emerging markets, so for example, China. In the United States, which of course, is a significant percentage of our overall business, approximately 50%. We've had a very productive year this year with new to cruise, and in fact, over time, it had been slightly on the decline. This year, we've turned that around, and we've seen a really positive increase in new to cruise. And of course, that's very much part of our focus is new to cruise, not only in emerging new and developing markets, but also in established markets like the U.S. So we feel quite encouraged about what we're seeing. And part of that is the campaign that we launched at the beginning of the year and also Celebrity's campaign. Both of those campaigns have components that are very much attractive to new to cruise. And when you do the research on how our positioning and how we're communicating resonates with new to cruise, it's very positive. So we're beginning to see that coming through in our bookings.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Richard, and I'll just add a comment because we often get questions about trends and things that have changed. And it's clear the questions are geared to, is the world changing? Is this a trend in the exogenous variables affecting us? But as
componenttext: Dan, this is Richard, and I'll just add a comment because we often get questions about trends and things that have changed. And it's clear the questions are geared to, is the world changing? Is this a trend in the exogenous variables affecting us? But as Michael pointed out, we actually work to change trends, so there are periods of time where we, for example, as both Royal -- as Michael said, both Royal and Celebrity made a conscious decision this year that there was a stronger opportunity, a good opportunity with first-time cruisers. And so they actually focused more of their marketing, focused more on their message, and they actually worked to build that. So when you look at a trend, it's not just, is the world changing, but to some extent, it's also what we're doing to shift our customer base. And then that sometimes messes up nice trend lines when you're trying to extrapolate from external behavior.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. Yes, that's very helpful. I guess, just a second question here. I'm wondering how big the impact to net yields is from the new revenue management technology implemented a while back? And I guess, I'm wondering what inning we're in with respect
componenttext: Very good. Yes, that's very helpful. I guess, just a second question here. I'm wondering how big the impact to net yields is from the new revenue management technology implemented a while back? And I guess, I'm wondering what inning we're in with respect to its implementation. So just for some perspective, when airlines put in new revenue management, they tend to go slow. And I'm just kind of curious how you'd characterize where you are with respect to that to Royal?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question, Dan. I think it's one of those things that's impossible to quantify. And we put in new yield management systems several years ago. And every day that goes by, the yield management systems get stronger because the information
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question, Dan. I think it's one of those things that's impossible to quantify. And we put in new yield management systems several years ago. And every day that goes by, the yield management systems get stronger because the information from the past and how we read information of what's happening in local markets and so forth gets better and better. So it's surely a tailwind. To quantify it is next to impossible to do, but it really -- I think one of the greatest benefits it gives us is the ability to manage demand globally. And that allows us to seek the highest yield for every cabin that's available from anywhere in the world. And that's obviously great -- on a revenue management standpoint, it's also great to be able to take advantage of that diversification.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon with Berenberg.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stuart Gordon with Berenberg.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first one is, on the return on invested capital, does the Pullmantur change make any difference to the returns you make? And secondly, just on China, could you talk about how next year the changing proportion of capacity is movi
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first one is, on the return on invested capital, does the Pullmantur change make any difference to the returns you make? And secondly, just on China, could you talk about how next year the changing proportion of capacity is moving up -- moving from pure charter to a more direct distribution?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the ROIC side, on the invested capital side, there really is no difference because as I said in my remarks, we still own those assets. But surely, as we've been talking about for years, that Pullmantur was a turnaround opportunity, and this allows u
componenttext: So on the ROIC side, on the invested capital side, there really is no difference because as I said in my remarks, we still own those assets. But surely, as we've been talking about for years, that Pullmantur was a turnaround opportunity, and this allows us to limit some of those turnaround issues as well as get paid for our -- the ships and the services. So it's definitely accretive to ROIC but it's on the earnings side, not necessarily on the invested capital side. I'll let Michael take the China question.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stuart, yes. On the evolution of distribution, that's something obviously that we've been focused on for quite some time. It's a journey that we're taking. I think what we're seeing is the beginnings of the development of distribution in terms of starting
componenttext: Stuart, yes. On the evolution of distribution, that's something obviously that we've been focused on for quite some time. It's a journey that we're taking. I think what we're seeing is the beginnings of the development of distribution in terms of starting to mirror and look very much like the North American distribution model. In terms of -- our focus very much is engaged in opening all channels to market and optimizing each channel. That includes our wholesaler charterer model, which we believe has done exceptionally well up to this point and we're going to continue working with our charterers. But we're also developing direct. We're also developing retail, next cruise, and that's very much what we've been engaged in over some time now. So I think that's a journey we're taking, and over time, we'll see the mix balance out in a very similar way to the other markets -- more developed markets.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Victoria, we have time for one more question.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Certainly. Your final question comes from the line of Ben Chaiken with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on Europe and the North American consumer. What are you doing this year to encourage those customers to return? Is there any education process or promotions? If so, when did that start? And is that with the travel agents or the customers
componenttext: Just following up on Europe and the North American consumer. What are you doing this year to encourage those customers to return? Is there any education process or promotions? If so, when did that start? And is that with the travel agents or the customers directly?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think it's necessary education. I just think there's been less events that have -- that turned off certain consumers last year, and as I said before, is allowing them to revisit the opportunity to go to beautiful and great destinations in Eur
componenttext: Yes. I don't think it's necessary education. I just think there's been less events that have -- that turned off certain consumers last year, and as I said before, is allowing them to revisit the opportunity to go to beautiful and great destinations in Europe. And I think that's probably more of what it is versus anything specifically we're doing in terms of education.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And can you remind us what the overall net yield decline was in Europe for '16 that we're going to lap next year?
componenttext: Got it. And can you remind us what the overall net yield decline was in Europe for '16 that we're going to lap next year?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given that number, but it is down year-over-year.
componenttext: We haven't given that number, but it is down year-over-year.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you going to quantify some of this positive trend that you're referring to with the North American consumer coming into Europe?
componenttext: Okay. And are you going to quantify some of this positive trend that you're referring to with the North American consumer coming into Europe?

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the only thing I could quantify is that we're ahead on both rate and volume next year relative to same time last year. Thank you for your assistance, Victoria, with the call today. And we thank you all for your participation and interest i
componenttext:
Well, I mean, the only thing I could quantify is that we're ahead on both rate and volume next year relative to same time last year. 
Thank you for your assistance, Victoria, with the call today. And we thank you all for your participation and interest in the company. Carol will be available for any follow-up questions you might have, and we all wish you a great day. Take care.

headline: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Again, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's call. You may now disconnect.
